سورہ القاساس کی یہ آیت مومنوں کو یاد دلاتی ہے کہ الہی رہنمائی (HUDA) بالآخر اللہ کے ہاتھ میں ہے ، جو انسانی خواہشات یا کوششوں سے بالاتر ہے۔ حضرت محمد صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم (ان پر امن ہے) ، ان کے چچا ابو طالب اور ان کی رہنمائی کرنے کی مخلصانہ کوششوں سے ان کی گہری محبت کے باوجود ، بتایا گیا کہ ایمان کی قبولیت اللہ کی مرضی پر منحصر ہے۔ تاریخی ذرائع ، بشمول شیعہ تبصرے جیسے طافسیر المزان کے ذریعہ الامہ تبتابائی ، اس آیت کو ابو طالب کے معاملے سے جوڑتے ہیں: اگرچہ انہوں نے نبی کی حفاظت کی اور اسلام کی سیاسی طور پر اس کی حمایت کی ، لیکن انہوں نے باضابطہ طور پر اس عقیدے کو قبول نہیں کیا۔ اس سے یہ بات اس بات کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے کہ نبی بھی عقیدے پر مجبور نہیں ہوسکتے ہیں - قیامت ایک الہی تحفہ (توفیق) ہے جسے اللہ تعالی اپنی حکمت پر مبنی ، انسانی منسلکات پر مبنی نہیں دیتا ہے۔

یہاں کلیدی شرائط * طاہدی * (رہنمائی کرنے کے لئے) اور * یشا * (وہ چاہیں) ہیں۔ * طاہدی* کا مطلب یہ ہے کہ کسی کو اندرونی یقین اور روحانی وضاحت کی طرف راغب کیا جائے ، جو صرف اللہ ہی سہولت فراہم کرتا ہے۔ * یشا* دلوں پر اللہ کی خودمختاری پر زور دیتا ہے۔ وہ ان لوگوں کے لئے رہنمائی کرتا ہے جن کی روحیں کھلی اور قابل قبول ہیں۔ وہ جملہ * وہ سب سے زیادہ صحیح ہدایت یافتہ * (وا ہووا ایلامو بل موہتدین) کے بارے میں سب سے زیادہ جانتا ہے ، مومنوں کو یقین دلاتا ہے کہ اللہ کا علم جو روحانی طور پر تیار ہے اس کا علم انسانی تاثر سے تجاوز کرتا ہے۔

عصری مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت اللہ کے منصوبے پر عاجزی اور اعتماد کی حوصلہ افزائی کرتی ہے۔ جب دوسروں کو اسلام کی دعوت دیتے ہیں تو ، کسی کو بھی ہمدردی کے ساتھ پیغام پہنچانا چاہئے لیکن اگر نتائج توقعات سے مختلف ہیں تو مایوسی سے بچیں۔ یہ یہ بھی سکھاتا ہے کہ پیاروں کی رہنمائی کے لئے مخلص ڈو (التجا) انتہائی ضروری ہے ، جو اس بات کو تسلیم کرنے کے ساتھ جوڑا بنا ہوا ہے کہ نتائج اللہ کے ساتھ باقی ہیں۔ مذہبی پولرائزیشن کے ذریعہ نشان زد دور میں ، یہ آیت ہمیں نتائج کو مجبور کرنے کے بجائے عقیدے کو مجسم بنانے پر توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہوئے ، خدائی حکمت کے حوالے کرنے کے ساتھ پوری کوشش میں توازن برقرار رکھنے کی یاد دلاتی ہے۔

*طافسیر المزان*میں ، علامہ تبتابائی اس آیت کو*وارنر*اور*الہی پیغام*اور روحانی رہنمائی (*ہیڈا*) کے اللہ کی خصوصی اختیار کے طور پر نبی of کے کردار کے مابین اونٹولوجیکل امتیاز پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ آیت اس کے چچا ابو طالب کے اسلام کو مسترد کرنے پر نبی کے غم کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے ، اور اس بات کی تصدیق کرتی ہے کہ یہاں تک کہ رسول بھی عقیدے پر مجبور نہیں ہوسکتا ہے ، کیونکہ رہنمائی بالآخر اللہ کی حکمت میں ایک الہی تعصب ہے۔ تبتابائی نے دعوی کیا ہے کہ*ہیڈا*یہاں سے مراد*توفیک* - روحانی استقبال کی عطا کرنا - جو اللہ ان لوگوں کو عطا کرتا ہے جن کی فطری رجحان (*فٹرا*) آزاد مرضی کے ذریعہ سچائی کے ساتھ سیدھ میں ہے۔ شیعہ الہیات نے اس بات کی نشاندہی کی ہے کہ جب نبی اور امام الہی رہنمائی ظاہر کرتے ہیں ، اس کی قبولیت کا انحصار انسانی انتخاب اور خدائی فضل پر ہے۔

الاتبریسی ،*ماجما البیان*میں ، الہی انصاف (*‘ADL*) اور انسانی احتساب کے اصول کے تحت آیت کو سیاق و سباق سے دوچار کرتا ہے۔ انہوں نے واضح کیا کہ رہنمائی میں اللہ کی مرضی مقصد اور اثر کے ایک فریم ورک کے ذریعے کام کرتی ہے: خدائی فضل فرد کی سچائی کے لئے مخلصانہ جدوجہد کا جواب دیتا ہے۔ جملہ*"وہ [بجا طور پر] رہنمائی کے بارے میں سب سے زیادہ جانتا ہے"*اللہ کے پہلے سے متعلق علم (*‘Ilm almhayb*) کی عکاسی کرتا ہے کہ انسانی ایجنسی کی نفی کیے بغیر ، ان کی کائناتی حکم کے ساتھ کون ان کی مرضی کی صف بندی کرے گا۔ یہ * امر بائن الامرین * (الہی فرمان کو آزادانہ مرضی کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ کرنے) کے شیعہ عقائد اور اللہ تعالٰی کے * ہیڈیا * پوسٹ پروفیت محمد (ایس) کو چینل کرنے کے لئے خدائی طور پر مقرر کردہ رہنما (آئی ایم اے ایم) کی ضرورت کے ساتھ صف بندی کرتا ہے۔

56.layer5:
This verse (28:56) addressing the limits of prophetic authority in granting guidance has been interpreted through complementary theological lenses in Shia and Sunni exegesis. Both traditions concur that the verse affirms Allah’s absolute sovereignty in granting *hidayah* (guidance), with scholars like Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) emphasizing that even the Prophet Muhammad ﷺ could not override divine will in matters of spiritual direction. Al-Qurtubi and Al-Tabrisi similarly note the verse’s historical context regarding the Prophet’s concern for his uncle Abu Talib, underscoring the theological principle that human desires—even noble ones—are subordinate to Allah’s wisdom.  

A key divergence arises in reconciling divine decree with human responsibility. Sunni commentators like Ibn Kathir and Al-Razi often frame this within the Ash‘ari emphasis on Allah’s unrestricted will (*mashee’ah*), interpreting the verse as affirming *qadar* (predestination). In contrast, Shia exegetes such as Al-Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) and Al-Qummi integrate the verse with the Imami concept of *lutf* (divine grace), arguing that Allah’s will operates through the ontological guidance provided by the Ahl al-Bayt. While both traditions cite the verse to reject coercion in faith, Shia interpretations frequently link it to the necessity of divinely appointed guides after the Prophet.  

Historically, these differences reflect distinct theological frameworks: Sunni exegesis developed alongside debates on predestination vs. free will, while Shia readings evolved within narratives of imamate and esoteric knowledge. Practically, the verse inspires humility in proselytization across both traditions, though Shia applications may emphasize allegiance to the Imams as channels of divine guidance. Despite interpretive variances, all cited scholars—from Al-Tabari to Al-Tabatabai—unite in viewing the verse as a reminder of divine transcendence beyond human partialities.

56.layer2short: In *Tafsir al-Mizan*, Allama Tabatabai elucidates this verse by emphasizing the ontological distinction between the Prophet’s (s) role as a *warner* and *bearer of divine message* and Allah’s exclusive authority over spiritual guidance (*hidaya*). The verse addresses the Prophet’s grief over his uncle Abu Talib’s rejection of Islam, affirming that even the Messenger cannot compel belief, as guidance is ultimately a divine prerogative rooted in Allah’s wisdom. Tabatabai asserts that *hidaya* here refers to *tawfiq*—the granting of spiritual receptivity—which Allah bestows upon those whose innate disposition (*fitra*) aligns with truth through free will. Shia theology underscores that while prophets and Imams manifest divine guidance, its acceptance depends on human choice and divine grace.

57.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qasas verse 57, Allah addresses the fear-based excuses made by the Quraysh leaders who resisted Islam, claiming that embracing the Prophet’s message would lead to their expulsion from Mecca and loss of livelihood. The verse exposes their shortsightedness by reminding them of Allah’s enduring protection and provision. The term *haram amin* (secure sanctuary) refers to Mecca’s divinely ordained status as a safe haven where trade caravans and agricultural yields (*thamaratu kulli shay*—fruits of all things) flowed freely, ensuring their sustenance as *rizqan min ladunna* (provision from Us). Their argument collapses under this divine rebuttal: how could they fear displacement when Allah Himself had established their security and abundance?

Historically, this verse reflects the Quraysh’s materialistic mindset during the Meccan period. They prioritized economic stability and tribal dominance over truth, fearing that accepting Islam would destabilize their pagan pilgrimage economy centered around the Kaaba. The verb *nutakhattaf* (to be swept away) captures their exaggerated dread of sudden ruin, contrasting sharply with Allah’s tangible blessings. 

For contemporary Muslims, this verse warns against allowing worldly anxieties—career pressures, social acceptance, or financial security—to overshadow faith. Just as the Quraysh overlooked Allah’s guarantees, modern believers might hesitate to uphold Islamic principles, wear hijab, or speak against injustice due to fear of repercussions. The verse reassures that Allah’s system of provision and protection operates beyond human calculations, urging trust in His plan over short-term comforts. It invites reflection on whether we, like the Quraysh, fixate on transient “land” (status, wealth, or societal approval) while ignoring the eternal *rizq* and *aman* (security) flowing from divine grace. As taught by the Ahlul Bayt, true success lies in aligning our priorities with Allah’s wisdom, not fleeting worldly logic.
57.layer2:
In Surah Al-Qasas verse 57, Allah addresses the objections of the Quraysh, who claimed that embracing the Prophet’s (ṣ) guidance would jeopardize their worldly security. Classical Shia exegetes emphasize the theological tension between divine tawḥīd (oneness) and human shortsightedness in prioritizing material comfort over eternal truth. As articulated by Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, the verse critiques the disbelievers’ flawed reasoning: Allah had already granted them the sacred ḥaram (Mecca) as a divinely protected sanctuary, abundant with provisions from "every fruit" as a sign of His sustainership (rizq min ladunnā). Their professed fear of displacement contradicted this manifest blessing, exposing their spiritual blindness to Allah’s signs and their ingratitude for His niʿma (favor).

Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* contextualizes this verse within the Quraysh’s political anxieties, noting their hypocrisy in valuing tribal prestige over submission to divine will. The "secure sanctuary" symbolizes not only physical safety but also the ontological reality of Allah’s absolute sovereignty over sustenance and security. Shia theology interprets such divine provisions as tests (ibtilā’) to gauge recognition (maʿrifa) of Allah’s authority and the necessity of aligning worldly life with transcendent purpose. As Tabatabai observes, their rejection of guidance despite these blessings exemplifies the Quranic axiom that "most of them do not know" – a recurring indictment of those who privilege superficial customs over divinely ordained truth.

This verse implicitly underscores the Shia understanding of wilayah (divinely ordained authority), as true security lies not in earthly power but in adherence to prophetic guidance and its continuity through the Ahl al-Bayt (as). The ḥaram’s theological significance extends to the broader Islamic framework of hijra (migration) for faith’s preservation, reinforcing that temporal attachments must never supersede obedience to divine command. Thus, the verse serves as a timeless admonition against allowing material complacency to obstruct spiritual awakening.
57.layer3:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:57), the Quran addresses a recurring human dilemma: the tension between clinging to material security and embracing moral or spiritual guidance. The verse critiques those who resist divine truth out of fear of displacement or loss of privilege, contrasting their anxieties with Allah’s assurance of sustenance and protection. Contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi and philosopher Mohammad Ali Shomali emphasize that this verse isn’t merely historical but speaks to modern struggles where individuals and communities prioritize economic or political stability over justice and truth. Shirazi notes in *Tafsir Nemooneh* that the “safe sanctuary” (haram amin) symbolizes both physical security and the ethical imperative to cultivate societies where resources are equitably distributed—a theme resonant in debates about climate justice, refugee crises, and economic inequality today.  

Scientifically, the verse’s mention of “fruits of all things” as divine provision invites reflection on ecological interdependence. Modern agricultural systems and global supply chains, while technologically advanced, often exploit ecosystems and labor, undermining the Quranic vision of sustainable rizq (sustenance). Socially, the verse critiques systemic greed: corporations and governments that prioritize profit over people mirror the Meccan elites’ fear of losing control. Philosophically, it challenges the illusion of self-sufficiency, urging trust in transcendent wisdom amid uncertainty—a counterpoint to modern materialism.  

Interfaith parallels abound: the concept of sanctuary as a shared Abrahamic value (e.g., cities of refuge in Judaism, church asylum traditions) underscores universal human needs for safety and dignity. In a polarized world, this verse calls for courage to align with ethical principles, trusting that justice—not mere survival—is the foundation of true security.
57.layer4:
In this profound verse, Allah responds to those fearing material loss by affirming His divine sustenance through the secure sanctuary of Mecca. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) unveil deeper layers: the "safe sanctuary" symbolizes the spiritual refuge of Wilayah (divine guardianship) and the Imamah. Imam Muhammad al-Baqir (as) taught, *"The true Haram (sanctuary) is the Imam from us; whoever enters his guardianship is secure from the fire"* (Bihar al-Anwar). Just as physical fruits gather in Mecca, spiritual blessings flow through devotion to the Imams, the channels of Allah’s mercy.  

The verse critiques prioritizing worldly stability over truth. Imam Ali (as) warned, *"The world is a corpse; whoever seeks it is a dog"* (Ghurar al-Hikam), urging detachment from fleeting attachments. Lady Fatimah (as) exemplified this, declaring, *"Allah made faith your purification from shirk…"* (Tuhaf al-Uqoul), teaching that true security lies in surrendering to divine will.  

The phrase "most of them do not know" reflects ignorance of the Imam’s role as the living Quranic interpreter. Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (as) explained, *"Allah’s rope is the Imams; holding to them saves from misguidance"* (Al-Kafi). To "follow guidance" despite fear requires tawakkul (trust in Allah), recognizing that spiritual provision outweighs material risk.  

Practical guidance: Anchor your heart to the Imams through daily supplications (duas) and studying their teachings. When worldly anxieties arise, recall Imam al-Kazim’s (as) advice: *"Seek sustenance through obedience [to Allah], for the key to provision is in His hands alone"* (Bihar al-Anwar). True safety lies not in land but in loyalty to the Ahlul Bayt, the eternal sanctuary of light.

57.layer5:
This verse addresses the Meccan leaders’ objection to Prophet Muhammad’s message, fearing displacement if they embraced Islam. Both Shia and Sunni exegetes agree the verse critiques prioritizing material security over divine guidance, emphasizing Allah’s establishment of Mecca as a divinely protected sanctuary (*haram*) with abundant sustenance. Tabari (Sunni) and Tabatabai (Shia) concur that the Quraysh’s reluctance stemmed from misplaced attachment to worldly status, disregarding Allah’s guarantee of safety for those who uphold truth. Ibn Kathir and Tabrisi similarly highlight the irony of their fear despite enjoying Mecca’s unique blessings, underscoring a shared theme of divine testing through temporal comforts.  

Divergences emerge in theological emphasis. Sunni commentators like Qurtubi and Razi frame the verse as a broader lesson on trusting divine providence, linking Mecca’s sanctity to Allah’s universal mercy. Shia scholars, however, often contextualize the critique within the paradigm of *wilayah* (allegiance to divine leadership). Al-Qummi and Tusi, drawing on Imami traditions, interpret the “guidance” as inseparable from adherence to the Ahlul Bayt, suggesting the Meccans’ rejection prefigured later oppositions to the Imams. This reflects the Shia theological focus on divine authority vested in the Prophet’s household.  

Historically, Sunni interpretations developed within frameworks prioritizing communal unity and Allah’s omnipotence, while Shia exegesis evolved alongside doctrines of Imamah, viewing spiritual and temporal guidance as intertwined. These differences subtly influence religious perspectives: Sunni thought emphasizes gratitude for divine blessings and communal resilience, whereas Shia teachings reinforce loyalty to divinely appointed leaders as integral to accepting guidance. Both traditions, however, unite in condemning materialism that obstructs faith, affirming the Quran’s timeless relevance across interpretive schools.

57.layer2short: In Surah Al-Qasas verse 57, Allah addresses the objections of the Quraysh, who claimed that embracing the Prophet’s (ṣ) guidance would jeopardize their worldly security. Classical Shia exegetes emphasize the theological tension between divine tawḥīd (oneness) and human shortsightedness in prioritizing material comfort over eternal truth. As articulated by Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, the verse critiques the disbelievers’ flawed reasoning: Allah had already granted them the sacred ḥaram (Mecca) as a divinely protected sanctuary, abundant with provisions from "every fruit" as a sign of His sustainership (rizq min ladunnā). Their professed fear of displacement contradicted this manifest blessing, exposing their spiritual blindness to Allah’s signs and their ingratitude for His niʿma (favor).

58.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qasas verse 58, Allah reminds humanity of His power to dismantle civilizations steeped in arrogance and ingratitude. The verse states: *"And how many a city have We destroyed that was insolent in its [way of] living, and those are their dwellings which have not been inhabited after them except briefly. And it is We who were the inheritors."* The term *"batirat ma'ishataha"* (insolent in its living) captures the essence of communities corrupted by materialism and pride in their prosperity, believing their wealth and power were self-earned rather than divine blessings. The word *batirat* derives from *batar* – a spiritual disease of arrogance rooted in excess, condemned repeatedly in Quranic teachings and Shia narrations about the moral decay of past nations like ‘Ad and Thamud.  

Historical tafsir sources, including Imam Ali ibn Abi Talib’s sermons in *Nahj al-Balagha*, contextualise this verse as a warning against societal complacency. Civilizations that neglect divine laws, exploit resources unjustly, or mock prophets—as Pharaoh’s dynasty did—face annihilation, leaving behind empty ruins (*masakinuhum*) as symbols of their ephemeral dominance. The phrase *"wa kunna nahnu al-warithin"* (We are the inheritors) reaffirms Allah’s absolute ownership over creation: all worldly power is temporary, and ultimate sovereignty belongs to Him alone.  

For modern Muslims, this verse urges critical self-reflection. It challenges us to avoid the pitfalls of consumerism, inequity, and heedlessness (ghaflah) that distance societies from divine mercy. Shia ethics, as emphasised by scholars like Tabatabai, tie this to Imam Hussein’s stand at Karbala—a rejection of worldly corruption in favour of eternal principles. Practically, this means cultivating gratitude (shukr) for blessings, prioritising social justice, and recognising that true success lies in humility and stewardship, not material accumulation. By learning from the ruins of the past, we safeguard our communities from repeating history’s gravest errors.
58.layer2:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:58), Allah emphasizes the divine law of accountability for civilizations that succumb to arrogance (batr) despite material prosperity. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Shaykh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, interpret this verse as a universal warning against the spiritual corruption that arises when communities prioritize transient worldly comforts over gratitude to their Creator. The term *batirat* (insolent in livelihood) denotes a state of heedlessness bred by excessive material security, leading societies to reject prophetic guidance and ethical responsibility. Tabatabai observes that such arrogance blinds communities to their reliance on Allah, fostering oppression and moral decay, which inevitably invite divine intervention.

Tabrisi highlights that the phrase *lam tuskun min ba’dihim illa qalilan* ("not inhabited after them except briefly") underscores the ephemeral nature of worldly power. The annihilation of these communities serves as a tangible manifestation of Allah’s justice (*‘adl*) and His role as the ultimate Inheritor (*al-Warith*), to whom all creation returns. Shia theology uniquely contextualizes this within the framework of *Imamah*, where the preservation of divine guidance through the Ahl al-Bayt ensures that humanity is never devoid of moral leadership—even as rebellious nations face temporal extinction. The verse thus reinforces the Shi'i principle that material success is a trial (*ibtila’*), demanding stewardship (*istikhlaf*) rather than entitlement.

Jurisprudentially, the verse underscores the obligation to avoid extravagance (*israf*) and cultivate humility. Classical scholars link this to the ethical mandates in Quranic verses like 7:31 and hadiths from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq emphasizing moderation. The destruction of past nations stands as a perpetual admonition: prosperity without piety invites divine reclamation, while adherence to the guidance of the Ahl al-Bayt ensures salvation in both worlds.
58.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Qasas verse 58 is increasingly interpreted as a profound ecological and social warning. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, highlights the phrase “insolent in its way of living” (*batirat ma’eeshataha*) as a critique of societies prioritizing unchecked consumption over ethical stewardship—a theme amplified by modern environmental crises. Scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, director of the International Institute for Islamic Studies, frame the verse’s destruction of arrogant civilizations as a metaphor for systemic collapse caused by humanity’s disconnect from divine balance (*mizan*), pointing to climate change and resource depletion as tangible consequences of this imbalance.

Modern scientific insights reinforce this interpretation. The IPCC’s 2023 report on desertification and abandoned settlements—like ancient Petra or modern-day ghost towns in drought-stricken regions—mirror the verse’s imagery of desolate dwellings. Philosophers such as Dr. Fatimah Sajjad (Al-Mahdi Institute) link the “inheritor” motif to humanity’s custodianship (*khilafa*) of Earth, arguing that extractive capitalism violates this sacred trust. Interfaith parallels emerge in Pope Francis’ *Laudato Si’*, which echoes the Quranic call to reject exploitative lifestyles harming marginalized communities. 

Socially, the verse critiques neoliberal excesses widening inequality—a theme explored by Iranian sociologist Dr. Zohreh Elahian in her analysis of Tehran’s luxury tower projects displacing low-income residents. The destruction of “insolent” cities becomes a cautionary tale for megacities prioritizing GDP over human dignity. Contemporary Shia ethics, as articulated by Ayatollah Sayyid Fadhel Milani, urge reimagining development through Imam Ali’s principle of *tawazun* (equilibrium), balancing material progress with spiritual and ecological integrity. In an age of climate refugees and corporate greed, this verse challenges humanity to choose sustainability over self-destruction.
58.layer4:
The verse from Surah Al-Qasas serves as a profound reminder of the spiritual consequences of arrogance and ingratitude, themes deeply emphasized in the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (as). The phrase "insolent in its way of living" reflects a heart hardened by worldly attachment, forgetting that sustenance is a divine trust. Imam Ali (as) states, "Gratitude is the shield against annihilation; whoever thanks Allah is secured from His punishment" (*Ghurar al-Hikam*). Here, "batirat ma'ishataha" signifies a community’s abandonment of humility and recognition of Allah’s blessings, leading to spiritual and physical ruin.  

The Ahlul Bayt (as) taught that true sustenance lies in proximity to divine guardianship (*Wilayah*). Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) explained, "The ‘inheritors’ in this verse are the purified Imams (as), for they inherit the knowledge and authority of the earth after its people corrupt it" (*Tafsir al-Qummi*). This connects the verse to the eternal truth that Allah’s chosen guides alone preserve balance in creation. When societies reject the light of Imamah, their material abundance becomes a curse, hollowing their souls until their legacy vanishes.  

Lady Fatimah (as), in her timeless sermon, warned against clinging to transient worldly possessions: "Beware of the world, for it is a passing shadow. Its delight does not last, and its evils are a trap" (*Bihar al-Anwar*). Practically, this verse urges believers to cultivate gratitude through daily remembrance (*dhikr*), detachment from materialism, and allegiance to the Ahlul Bayt (as). The spiritual "cities" within our hearts thrive only when built on humility, service, and unwavering loyalty to the Imams—the true inheritors of divine truth. Let every blessing received be a bridge to worship, not arrogance, and a means to draw nearer to the Ma’sumin (as)

58.layer5:
This verse from Surah Al-Qasas (28:58) addressing the destruction of arrogant communities has drawn convergent and divergent insights from Shia and Sunni exegetes. Both traditions broadly agree on the verse’s core themes: divine punishment for ingratitude and arrogance (batr), the ephemerality of worldly power, and Allah’s ultimate sovereignty as the “Inheritor” of all creation. Sunni commentators like Ibn Kathir and Tabari emphasize historical precedents—such as the annihilation of ‘Ād and Thamūd—as universal warnings against moral corruption, aligning with Shia scholars including Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan), who similarly stress the link between societal decay and divine retribution. Qurtubi and Razi highlight the ethical imperative of humility in prosperity, a point echoed in Tusi’s At-Tibyan, which underscores the transient nature of material wealth.

A key divergence emerges in contextual interpretations. Sunni exegeses often frame the verse as a general admonition against individual and collective hubris, with Tabari and Ibn Kathir linking it to pre-Islamic communities’ rejection of prophets. In contrast, Shia sources like Qummi’s Tafsir and Tabatabai’s Al-Mizan frequently situate such narratives within the theological framework of walāyah (divinely ordained leadership), interpreting societal destruction as a consequence of rejecting rightful guides. This reflects the Shia emphasis on Imamah as a protective institution against spiritual and moral bankruptcy, a concept less pronounced in Sunni tafsir.

Theological foundations further shape these differences: Sunni interpretations rooted in the primacy of prophetic Sunnah and communal accountability, while Shia readings integrate Imam Ali and the Ahl al-Bayt’s teachings as essential to societal preservation. Historically, these distinctions arise from early epistemological divergences regarding religious authority post-Prophet Muhammad. Both traditions, however, reinforce the verse’s practical implications—encouraging gratitude, ethical stewardship, and recognition of divine sovereignty—demonstrating shared ethical priorities despite differing hermeneutical lenses.

59.layer1:
This verse from Surah Al-Qasas establishes a profound principle of divine justice: Allah never destroys communities without first sending them clear guidance through a messenger. The phrase "yab'atha fi ummiha rasulan" (sends to their mother city a messenger) uses "umm" (mother) symbolically, referring to a community’s central hub or spiritual heartland, where prophets typically began their missions. Historically, this verse comforted early Muslims facing persecution in Mecca, reminding them that even powerful oppressors like Pharaoh faced consequences only after rejecting prophets like Musa (Moses), who recited "ayatina" (Our signs) – revelations proving Allah’s truth.

Key terms like "muhlik" (destroyer) and "zalamun" (wrongdoers) highlight that destruction isn’t arbitrary but follows persistent injustice after guidance. Shia tafsir, including Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, emphasises Allah’s mercy in granting every society a fair chance through divine envoys. Imam Ali’s teachings in *Nahj al-Balagha* link this to leadership responsibility: just as prophets warn communities, leaders must uphold justice to prevent societal collapse.

Today, this verse urges Muslims to balance patience and principled action. It reinforces the duty to share Islam’s message compassionately before judging others, recognising that modern technology expands our capacity to convey truth. Simultaneously, it condemns complacency towards oppression (zulm), whether in corrupt systems or personal conduct. For Shias, it resonates with the belief in the Imam’s role as a guide; just as past prophets were sent to avert destruction, following the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings protects spiritual and communal integrity. Ultimately, it reassures believers that divine justice prevails – no soul is wronged without warning, and no tyranny escapes accountability.
59.layer2:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:59), the Quran establishes a foundational principle of divine justice: Allah does not impose collective punishment upon a community without first sending a messenger to convey His guidance. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, emphasize that this verse underscores Allah’s *lutf* (divine grace) and the necessity of clear prophetic guidance before accountability. The "mother of the cities" (umm al-qura) is interpreted as the central hub of a region, from which divine messages radiate to encompass all its inhabitants, ensuring universal access to truth before judgment. This aligns with the Shia theological tenet that divine justice necessitates the uninterrupted presence of guides—Prophets and, subsequently, the Imams—to preserve and propagate revelation.

Tabrisi notes that the verse’s emphasis on sending messengers reflects Allah’s mercy, as destruction only occurs when communities persistently reject guidance and engage in *zulm* (oppression). In Shia thought, *zulm* extends beyond general wrongdoing to include the rejection of the divinely appointed leadership of the Ahl al-Bayt, as articulated by Imam Jafar al-Sadiq. Tabatabai further elucidates that the verse implicitly affirms the continuity of divine guidance through the Imamate, as the moral and spiritual "cities" of humanity cannot be left without a guide even after the final Prophet. This ties to the Shia doctrine of *Imamah*, which positions the Imams as inheritors of prophetic wisdom and guardians against societal deviation.

Jurisprudentially, the verse reinforces the principle that accountability in Islamic law requires prior knowledge of obligations—a concept mirrored in the legal maxim *la taklif illa bi’l-balagh* (no obligation without communication). Thus, the verse not only addresses divine judgment but also shapes ethical and legal frameworks, emphasizing the inseparability of divine mercy, human responsibility, and the necessity of guided leadership.
59.layer3:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:59), the Quran establishes a profound principle of divine justice: no society faces annihilation until it has first been given clear guidance through a divinely sent messenger. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi and Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, emphasize this verse as a universal ethical framework. They highlight that God’s “messengers” are not limited to prophets but extend to *ulul amr* (righteous leaders) and even the innate moral conscience embedded in humanity—a concept echoed in the *fitrah* theology discussed by thinkers like Sayyid Hussein Nasr. This aligns with modern philosophical debates on moral responsibility and collective accountability in pluralistic societies.

Modern applications of this verse resonate in discussions about climate justice and systemic oppression. For instance, scholars like Dr. Fatemeh Mashhadi contextualize the “destruction” metaphorically, linking it to ecological collapse caused by human greed. The verse’s warning against *zulm* (oppression/injustice) mirrors the UN’s Sustainable Development Goals, which frame environmental degradation as a consequence of exploitative systems. Similarly, social movements for equity—from anti-corruption protests in the Global South to Black Lives Matter—embody the Quranic call to heed “messengers” advocating for transformative justice.

Interfaith parallels emerge here: Jewish teachings on *tikkun olam* (repairing the world) and Christian liberation theology both stress divine mercy contingent on ethical action. In multicultural contexts, this verse invites dialogue on shared human responsibility. As Ayatollah Taskhiri noted in interreligious councils, divine justice transcends borders—today’s “cities” are global systems, and their salvation lies in heeding moral voices, whether secular or sacred. The verse thus becomes a timeless call to recognize that societal collapse is never inevitable; it is the endpoint of ignored warnings and unaddressed inequities.

The Ahlul Bayt (عليهم السلام) teach that the “mother city” (Umm al-Qura) symbolizes the spiritual heart of humanity, where the light of guidance must first dawn. Imam Ali (عليه السلام) states in *Nahj al-Balagha*: “Allah does not take a servant to task until He establishes the proof against him.” Here, the “messenger” sent to the “mother city” transcends mere prophets; it encompasses the chain of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) through the Imams, who carry the living message of the Quran across generations.  

Imam Ja’far al-Sadiq (عليه السلام) explains in *Tafsir al-Qummi*: “The ‘messenger’ in this verse refers to the Proof of Allah (Hujjah) in every era. When people reject him, their cities—their souls and societies—crumble through their own oppression.” The “wrongdoers” are those who deny the Imam of their time, severing their connection to divine mercy. Lady Fatimah (عليها السلام) echoes this in her sermon: “Allah made obedience to us the covenant of His religion and the purification from sins.”  

Spiritually, this verse calls believers to anchor their hearts in the *Wilayah* of the Ahlul Bayt, the ark of salvation. Practical guidance lies in seeking their teachings daily, aligning actions with their morals, and recognizing that rejecting their love and authority is the essence of *Dhulm* (oppression). As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (عليه السلام) teaches in *Sahifa al-Sajjadiyya*: “The ruin of nations begins when they exchange divine truths for fleeting desires.” To thrive, one must uphold the Imamah as the rope of Allah, clinging to it with sincerity, humility, and unwavering faith.

59.layer5:
This verse underscores divine justice in holding communities accountable only after sending messengers to convey guidance. Both Shia and Sunni exegetes agree on its core principle: Allah’s punishment is contingent upon rejecting clear revelation after its transmission. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) concur that the “mother city” (umm) refers to a central community or spiritual nucleus, with messengers sent to establish universal moral accountability. Ibn Kathir and Al-Mizan’s Tabatabai both emphasize that destruction follows persistent injustice (*zulm*) after guidance, aligning with Quranic themes of divine mercy preceding judgment.  

Divergences emerge in interpreting the scope of divine guidance. Sunni commentators like Al-Qurtubi and Al-Razi focus on prophets as exclusive bearers of revelation, stressing the finality of Muhammad’s message. In contrast, Shia sources such as Al-Qummi and Al-Tusi extend the principle to include the Imams’ role as inheritors of prophetic guidance. Tabatabai argues in *Al-Mizan* that the verse implies a continuous chain of divine representatives (Imams) ensuring access to truth, reflecting the Shia belief in *walayah* (divinely ordained leadership). This theological distinction arises from differing views on authority post-Muhammad: Sunni thought prioritizes textual and communal consensus, while Shia tradition elevates the Imam’s infallible interpretive role.  

Historically, these interpretations reflect early debates over leadership and spiritual authority. Sunni exegesis developed within a framework affirming the closure of prophethood, whereas Shia readings evolved alongside their Imamology. Both traditions, however, reinforce ethical responsibility: rejecting truth after its manifestation invites divine accountability. While the mechanisms of guidance differ, the verse’s moral imperative—heeding divine signs—remains a unifying ethical cornerstone.

الہی رہنمائی کے دائرہ کار کی ترجمانی میں تفریق ابھرتی ہے۔ سنی مبصرین جیسے القوروبی اور الراجی نبیوں پر توجہ مرکوز کرنے کے خصوصی بیئرر کی حیثیت سے نبیوں پر مرکوز کرتے ہیں ، اور محمد کے پیغام کی حتمی بات پر زور دیتے ہیں۔ اس کے برعکس ، شیعہ ذرائع جیسے القومی اور التوسی اس اصول کو بڑھا دیتے ہیں تاکہ اماموں کے پیشن گوئی کی رہنمائی کے وارث ہونے کے کردار کو شامل کیا جاسکے۔ تبتابائی نے * المزان * میں استدلال کیا ہے کہ اس آیت میں خدائی نمائندوں (آئی ایم اے ایم) کی ایک مستقل سلسلہ کا مطلب ہے جو سچ تک رسائی کو یقینی بناتا ہے ، جس سے * والیاہ * (خدائی طور پر مقرر قیادت) میں شیعہ عقیدے کی عکاسی ہوتی ہے۔ یہ مذہبی امتیاز اتھارٹی کے بارے میں مختلف نظریات سے پیدا ہوتا ہے جو محمد کے بعد: سنی سوچ نے متنی اور فرقہ وارانہ اتفاق رائے کو ترجیح دی ہے ، جبکہ شیعہ روایت امام کے ناقابل تسخیر تشریحی کردار کو بلند کرتی ہے۔  

تاریخی طور پر ، یہ تشریحات قیادت اور روحانی اتھارٹی کے بارے میں ابتدائی بحثوں کی عکاسی کرتی ہیں۔ سنی کی توثیق ایک فریم ورک کے اندر تیار ہوئی جس میں پیشن گوئی کی بندش کی تصدیق کی گئی تھی ، جبکہ شیعہ کی ریڈنگ ان کے امامولوجی کے ساتھ ساتھ تیار ہوئی ہے۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات اخلاقی ذمہ داری کو تقویت بخشتی ہیں: اس کے ظاہر ہونے کے بعد سچائی کو مسترد کرنا خدائی احتساب کی دعوت دیتا ہے۔ اگرچہ رہنمائی کے طریقہ کار مختلف ہیں ، لیکن آیت کی اخلاقی لازمی - ہیڈنگ الہی علامتوں کو متحد کرنے والی اخلاقی سنگ بنیاد ہے۔
59.layer2short: In Surah Al-Qasas (28:59), the Quran establishes a foundational principle of divine justice: Allah does not impose collective punishment upon a community without first sending a messenger to convey His guidance. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, emphasize that this verse underscores Allah’s *lutf* (divine grace) and the necessity of clear prophetic guidance before accountability. The "mother of the cities" (umm al-qura) is interpreted as the central hub of a region, from which divine messages radiate to encompass all its inhabitants, ensuring universal access to truth before judgment. This aligns with the Shia theological tenet that divine justice necessitates the uninterrupted presence of guides—Prophets and, subsequently, the Imams—to preserve and propagate revelation.
59.layer2short_urdu: سورہ القاساس (28:59) میں ، قرآن نے الہی انصاف کا ایک بنیادی اصول قائم کیا ہے: اللہ کسی کمیونٹی پر پہلے کسی میسنجر کو اپنی رہنمائی کے لئے بھیجے بغیر اجتماعی سزا نہیں دیتا ہے۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ ، جیسے *المزان *میں علامہ تبتابائی اور *مجس البییان *میں شیخ تبریسی ، اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ یہ آیت اس بات کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے کہ اللہ کے *لوٹف *(الہی فضل) اور احتساب سے پہلے واضح پیشن گوئی کی رہنمائی کی ضرورت ہے۔ "شہروں کی ماں" (ام القورا) کو کسی خطے کا مرکزی مرکز قرار دیا گیا ہے ، جہاں سے الہی پیغامات اپنے تمام باشندوں کو گھیرے میں لے جاتے ہیں ، جس سے فیصلے سے پہلے سچائی تک عالمی سطح پر رسائی کو یقینی بنایا جاتا ہے۔ یہ شیعہ مذہبی اصول کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہے کہ خدائی انصاف کے لئے گائڈز کی بلاتعطل موجودگی کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے۔

60.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qasas verse 60, Allah reminds humanity that all worldly possessions—wealth, status, or material comforts—are temporary adornments (*zinatuhā*) meant only for fleeting enjoyment (*matāʿ al-ḥayāt al-dunyā*). This verse, revealed during the Meccan period, addressed both the early Muslim community facing persecution and the affluent Quraysh who took pride in their wealth. It contrasts the transient "dunya" (worldly life) with the eternal blessings of the hereafter, urging reflection (*a-falā taʿqilūn*—"will you not use reason?") on life’s true purpose.  

Classical Shia commentators like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* emphasize that worldly resources are not inherently evil but become problematic when prioritized over spiritual growth. The verse criticizes those who mistake material success for divine favor, a notion challenged by the poverty of early Muslims and the oppression they endured. Key terms like *matāʿ* (enjoyment) and *abqā* ("more lasting") highlight the Qur’an’s recurring theme: worldly gains fade, while deeds done for Allah’s pleasure endure.  

For modern Muslims, this verse is a call to balance material responsibilities with spiritual awareness. It warns against consumerism, vanity, or measuring self-worth through possessions—a timely message in an age of social media and hyper-materialism. Practical applications include using wealth ethically (e.g., charity, supporting justice), valuing relationships over status, and investing in acts that outlive us, like knowledge or kindness. As Imam Ali taught, "Work for your worldly life as if you will live forever, and work for your hereafter as if you will die tomorrow"—embracing dunya as a means to serve Allah, not an end in itself. Ultimately, the verse invites believers to align their priorities with eternal truths, ensuring worldly blessings become bridges to divine proximity, not distractions from it.
60.layer2:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:60), Allah contrasts the ephemeral nature of worldly possessions with the enduring rewards of the hereafter, urging humanity to exercise reason in prioritizing eternal truths over transient materialism. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, emphasize that worldly provisions—wealth, status, or power—are merely a *tamattu'* (temporary enjoyment) and a test of human accountability. Tabatabai argues that the verse underscores the theological principle of *tawhid al-af'ali* (divine exclusivity in agency), wherein all worldly benefits are ultimately derived from Allah’s grace, yet their impermanence necessitates detachment (*zuhd*) to avoid spiritual heedlessness. 

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, elaborates that the "adornment" (*zinat*) of worldly life refers to superficial allurements that distract from the pursuit of divine proximity. He cites traditions from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, who cautioned that excessive attachment to worldly gains blinds the heart to the "light of guidance" (*nur al-hidayah*), a concept tied to the Shia belief in the Imam’s role as the spiritual illuminator of human intellect (*aql*). The verse’s rhetorical challenge—"Will you not use reason?"—resonates with the Shia theological emphasis on *aql* as a God-given tool to discern truth, aligned with the teachings of the Ahl al-Bayt. 

This verse also intersects with Shia jurisprudence, particularly in ethics (*akhlaq*) and economic conduct. Scholars like Shaykh al-Mufid interpret the call to prioritize Allah’s "better and lasting" rewards as an injunction to channel worldly resources toward acts of justice (*adl*) and charity (*sadaqah*), thereby transforming temporal means into eternal merit. The dichotomy here reflects the broader Shia worldview, wherein the material world is a bridge to the hereafter, navigated under the guidance of the Imams, who exemplify the balance between temporal responsibility and spiritual aspiration.
60.layer3:
In Surah Al-Qasas verse 60, Allah contrasts the fleeting nature of worldly possessions with the enduring value of divine blessings—a theme contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi contextualize within modern materialism. He emphasizes that while technology and wealth are tools for societal progress, their misuse as ends in themselves fosters spiritual emptiness, a notion echoed in philosopher Byung-Chul Han’s critique of “hyper-consumerism” as a crisis of modern existence. This verse, scholars argue, invites reflection on the ethical distribution of resources, urging societies to prioritize justice and compassion over accumulation—a stance amplified by figures like Ayatollah Sayyid Fadlullah, who linked Quranic warnings about worldly attachment to today’s climate crisis and wealth inequality.

Neuroscientific research on happiness, such as studies by Dr. Sonja Lyubomirsky, aligns with this spiritual worldview: material gains trigger temporary dopamine spikes, while lasting fulfillment stems from purpose and connection—mirroring the Quranic “what is with Allah.” Socially, the verse critiques systems that commodify human dignity, from exploitative labor practices to algorithmic consumerism, urging a reorientation toward “spiritual capitalism” (a term explored by scholar Tarek Elgawhary) that balances material needs with transcendent ethics. Philosophically, it parallels Buddhist detachment and Christian teachings on storing “treasures in heaven,” fostering interfaith dialogue on shared ethical imperatives.

In our era of climate collapse and AI-driven alienation, this verse becomes a manifesto for sustainable living and moral clarity. It challenges Muslims to leverage advancements in renewable energy, universal healthcare, and education as acts of worship, transforming worldly means into vehicles for eternal goals—a vision articulated by contemporary thinkers like Dr. Liyakat Takim, who bridges Islamic eschatology with global humanitarianism. Ultimately, the verse is a call to dismantle illusions of permanence in a transient world, grounding progress in justice and divine consciousness.

The Ahlul Bayt (as) taught that this verse is a mirror reflecting the reality of *zuhd* (detachment) – not the rejection of lawful provisions, but the cultivation of a heart anchored in divine priorities. Imam Ali (as) warned, *"The world is a corpse; whoever seeks it is a dog"* (al-Kafi), meaning chasing ephemeral gains degrades the soul’s nobility unless wealth becomes a tool for eternal investment.  

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) explained that *"what you have been given"* includes not only wealth but all worldly attachments that distract from remembrance of Allah. He taught that the *"better and lasting"* reward refers to the proximity (*qurb*) attained through loyalty (*wilayah*) to the Imams, the inheritors of divine knowledge. Lady Fatimah (as) declared in her iconic sermon: *"The world is a testing ground, the hereafter an eternal abode. Take from the passage for your destination"* – urging believers to use worldly means to build their akhirah through charity, prayer, and service.  

Practical wisdom lies in daily *muhasabah* (self-audit): Do our pursuits align with fleeting trends or eternal truths? The Imams taught that true richness is contentment with Allah’s decree while actively seeking His pleasure. By nurturing gratitude for blessings without becoming enslaved by them, believers transform every possession into a bridge toward Him. Regular recitation of *Ziyarat Ashura*, which affirms loyalty to Imam Husayn’s (as) eternal sacrifice, invigorates detachment from worldly illusions. Prioritize acts that outlive you: knowledge shared, justice upheld, and love for the Ahlul Bayt (as) cultivated – for these are the *"lasting"* treasures stored with our Lord.

* المزان * میں الامہ تبتابائی جیسے کلاسیکی شیعہ مبصرین اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ دنیاوی وسائل فطری طور پر برے نہیں ہیں بلکہ روحانی نشوونما پر ترجیح دیتے وقت پریشانی کا شکار ہوجاتے ہیں۔ آیت میں ان لوگوں پر تنقید کی گئی ہے جو خدائی احسان کے ل material مادی کامیابی کو غلطی کرتے ہیں ، یہ خیال ابتدائی مسلمانوں کی غربت اور ان کے جبر کو برداشت کرنے کے لئے چیلنج کیا گیا ہے۔ کلیدی اصطلاحات جیسے * مات āʿ * (لطف اندوزی) اور * اب کیو * ("مزید دیرپا") قرآن مجید کے بار بار چلنے والے تھیم کو اجاگر کرتے ہیں: دنیاوی فائدہ ختم ہوجاتے ہیں ، جبکہ اللہ کی خوشی کے لئے ہونے والے اعمال۔  

جدید مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت روحانی بیداری کے ساتھ مادی ذمہ داریوں کو متوازن کرنے کی کال ہے۔ یہ صارفیت ، باطل ، یا مالیت کے ذریعہ خود کی قدر کی پیمائش کے خلاف متنبہ کرتا ہے۔ یہ سوشل میڈیا اور ہائپر مادیت کے دور میں ایک بروقت پیغام ہے۔ عملی ایپلی کیشنز میں اخلاقی طور پر دولت کا استعمال (جیسے ، خیراتی ادارہ ، انصاف کی حمایت کرنا) ، حیثیت سے متعلق تعلقات کی قدر کرنا ، اور ایسی حرکتوں میں سرمایہ کاری کرنا شامل ہیں جو علم یا احسان کی طرح ہمیں پیچھے چھوڑ دیتے ہیں۔ جیسا کہ امام علی نے سکھایا ، "اپنی دنیاوی زندگی کے لئے کام کریں گویا آپ ہمیشہ کے لئے زندہ رہیں گے ، اور اپنے اس کے بعد کام کریں گے گویا کہ آپ کل مرجائیں گے" - ڈنیا کو اللہ کی خدمت کے ایک ذریعہ کے طور پر پیش کرتے ہوئے ، اپنے آپ کو ختم نہیں کرنا۔ بالآخر ، آیت مومنوں کو دعوت دیتی ہے کہ وہ اپنی ترجیحات کو ابدی سچائیوں کے ساتھ سیدھ میں لائیں ، اس بات کو یقینی بناتے ہوئے کہ دنیاوی نعمتیں الہی قربت کے پل بن جائیں ، اس سے خلفشار نہیں۔

سورہ القاساس (28:60) میں ، اللہ دنیاوی املاک کی حقیقت پسندی کی نوعیت کا متضاد ہے جس کے بعد کے بعد کے پائیدار انعامات کے ساتھ ، انسانیت پر زور دیا گیا ہے کہ وہ عارضی مادیت پر مبنی ابدی سچائیوں کو ترجیح دینے میں استدلال کریں۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ ، جیسے *المزان *میں علامہ تبتابائی ، اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ دنیاوی دفعات-ویلتھ ، اسٹیٹس ، یا طاقت-محض ایک *تمتو ' *(عارضی لطف اندوزی) اور انسانی احتساب کا امتحان ہے۔ تبتابائی نے استدلال کیا ہے کہ آیت*توحید الافالیلی*(ایجنسی میں خدائی استثنیٰ) کے مذہبی اصول کی نشاندہی کرتی ہے ، جس میں تمام دنیاوی فوائد بالآخر اللہ کے فضل سے حاصل کیے جاتے ہیں ، پھر بھی ان کی عدم استحکام کو روحانی بے حرمتی سے بچنے کے لئے لاتعلقی (*زہد*) کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے۔ 

تبریسی ،*مجسما البیان*میں ، وضاحت کرتے ہیں کہ دنیاوی زندگی کی "زینت" (*زینت*) سے مراد سطحی الیورمنٹس ہیں جو خدائی قربت کے حصول سے ہٹ جاتے ہیں۔ انہوں نے امام جعفر السادق کی روایات کا حوالہ دیا ، جنہوں نے متنبہ کیا کہ دنیاوی سے ضرورت سے زیادہ وابستگی دل کو "روشنی کی روشنی" (*نور الہیدہ*) سے اندھا کردیتی ہے ، یہ تصور انسانی عقل کے روحانی الیومینیٹر (*AQL*) کے طور پر امام کے کردار میں شیعہ عقیدے سے منسلک ہے۔ آیت کا بیان بازی کا چیلنج-"کیا آپ وجہ استعمال نہیں کریں گے؟"-اے ایچ ایل البائٹ کی تعلیمات کے ساتھ منسلک سچائی کو سمجھنے کے لئے خدا کے عطا کردہ آلے کے طور پر * AQL * پر شیعہ مذہبی زور سے گونجتا ہے۔

60.layer5:
In interpreting Qasas 60, Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core themes of worldly transience versus divine permanence. Both traditions, as seen in Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* and Ibn Kathir’s *Tafsir*, emphasize the Qur’anic dichotomy between material possessions (*mata‘ al-hayat al-dunya*) and eternal divine rewards. Al-Qurtubi and Al-Tabrisi similarly stress the verse’s ethical imperative to prioritize spiritual over temporal gains, urging believers to employ reason (*a-fala ta‘qilun*) in aligning worldly actions with otherworldly objectives.  

Key differences emerge in contextual framing. Sunni commentators like Al-Tabari and Al-Razi often situate the verse within narratives of prophetic struggles against materialism, citing historical figures like Qarun (Korah) as cautionary tales. Ibn Kathir links the admonition to Muhammad’s sunnah, framing detachment as prophetic emulation. Shia sources, particularly Al-Qummi and Al-Tusi, frequently connect the “lasting good with Allah” to the metaphysical status of the Ahl al-Bayt, interpreting divine rewards as encompassing both paradisal blessings and allegiance to the Imamate. Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* further distinguishes between worldly “adornment” (*zinataha*) as a test of spiritual priorities rather than an inherent evil, reflecting the Shia emphasis on intentionality in navigating material existence.  

These nuances influence practice: Sunni discourses often emphasize individual asceticism and charitable redistribution, while Shia interpretations may integrate material detachment with communal obligations under Imamah. Historically, Shia emphasis on the Ahl al-Bayt’s guidance reflects theological responses to political marginalization, whereas Sunni readings align with broader communal ethics shaped by caliphal governance models. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s core call to transcend materialism through reasoned faith.

61.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:61), Allah poses a profound rhetorical question contrasting two groups: those who embrace His "waʿdan ḥasanan" (good promise) of eternal reward and those consumed by "matāʿ al-ḥayāt al-dunyā" (the fleeting enjoyments of worldly life). The verse asks: Can the one destined for divine fulfillment through faith and righteous deeds ever be equated with those who chase temporary pleasures but face eternal ruin on Judgment Day? This powerful comparison, rooted in the Quranic theme of spiritual prioritization, underscores the transient nature of worldly gains against the permanence of the hereafter.

Historical accounts suggest this verse resonated during the Prophet’s (saw) Meccan era, when early Muslims faced persecution while wealthy Quraysh elites mocked their piety. The "good promise" refers not only to Paradise but also to divine support for the faithful amid trials, while "those presented for punishment" (al-muḥḍarīn) alludes to arrogant opponents who rejected truth despite clear signs. Shia exegetes like Allamah Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* emphasize that true believers are those who align with divine guidance—a theme later embodied in the loyalty to Imam Ali (as) and the Ahlul Bayt, who represent the living "good promise" of spiritual continuity.

Key terms like "laqīhi" (he will obtain) highlight the certainty of Allah’s covenant for the steadfast, contrasting with "matāʿ" (enjoyment), a term often linked in the Quran to superficial, temporary comforts. For contemporary Muslims, this verse calls for critical self-reflection: Are we investing in lasting spiritual wealth through Quranic values and the Ahlul Bayt’s teachings, or being seduced by consumerism, status, and instant gratification? It reminds us that worldly success without ethical grounding is a hollow victory, while patience in pursuing divine pleasure—even amid modern hardships—yields eternal triumph. The choice, as the verse starkly frames, defines our ultimate destiny.
61.layer2:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:61), the Qur'an contrasts the eternal reward promised to the righteous with the fleeting enjoyment granted to the worldly-minded, framing a profound theological inquiry central to Shia eschatology. Classical Shia exegetes, including Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Sheikh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, emphasize this verse’s dialectic on the nature of divine justice (*‘adl*) and the hierarchy of spiritual priorities.  

Tabatabai elucidates that the "good promise" (*wa‘dan hasanan*) refers explicitly to the covenant of ultimate felicity in the Hereafter, reserved for those who align their earthly existence with divine wilaya (allegiance to the Ahlul Bayt). This promise transcends material provisions, reflecting the Shia doctrine that true prosperity lies in proximity to the Divine through recognition of the Imamah. Conversely, the "enjoyment of worldly life" epitomizes temporal distractions that veil humanity from its cosmic purpose. Tabrisi notes that such individuals—symbolized by Pharaoh and his contemporaries—are "presented [for punishment]" not merely for disbelief but for actively rejecting truth despite their capacity for recognition, a theme recurrent in Qur’anic narratives of divine testing (*ibtila*).  

The verse’s rhetorical question underscores the futility of equating transient worldly gains with eternal reward, a principle reiterated in Shia hadith literature. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq is reported to have said, "The world is a market: some profit, others perish," highlighting the necessity of investing in spiritual capital. This dichotomy aligns with Shia jurisprudence’s emphasis on *zuhd* (ascetic detachment) and ethical accountability beyond ritual observance.  

Furthermore, the "presentation" on Judgment Day carries theological weight in Shia eschatology, wherein the oppressed (*mustad‘ifun*) and their oppressors face contrasting reckonings—a motif linked to the redemptive role of the Mahdi. Thus, the verse implicitly critiques materialism while affirming the Shia worldview’s metaphysical axis: allegiance to divine guidance as the sole path to salvation.  

Classical commentators unanimously stress that the verse challenges believers to transcend the *dunya*’s illusions, anchoring their hopes in the unshakeable promise of the Hereafter—a promise inseparable from the guardianship (*wilaya*) of the Ahlul Bayt.
61.layer3:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:61), the Quran poses a piercing question about the eternal stakes of worldly pursuits versus divine promise. Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi in *Tafsir Nemooneh*, frame this verse as a timeless critique of materialism, urging believers to weigh transient gains against everlasting spiritual consequences. Modern thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to today’s "success culture," where hyper-individualism and consumerism often eclipse ethical and spiritual priorities. The verse challenges societies obsessed with GDP growth but indifferent to poverty, climate collapse, or mental health crises—issues that reveal the emptiness of material "progress" divorced from higher purpose.  

Neuroscientific studies on happiness, cited by scholars in Islamic ethics, reinforce this dichotomy: dopamine-driven pleasures fade, while faith-based contentment and service to others activate deeper, sustained fulfillment. Philosophically, the verse mirrors existential debates about meaning—thinkers like Viktor Frankl’s *Man’s Search for Meaning* resonate here, emphasizing transcendence over temporary gratification.  

Interfaith parallels abound. Pope Francis’ critiques of capitalism’s "throwaway culture" and Buddhist teachings on detachment both echo Islam’s warning against worldly entanglement. In multicultural societies, this verse invites dialogue on shared values: environmental stewardship (tying to COP28’s climate justice themes), wealth redistribution, and resisting systems that reduce human dignity to economic output.  

Ultimately, the verse isn’t a rejection of worldly engagement but a call to align it with divine purpose—a balance scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim link to Imam Ali’s counsel to "work for your worldly life as if you will live forever, and for your hereafter as if you will die tomorrow." Today’s crises demand this integrated vision: thriving economies that honour both human need and sacred responsibility.
61.layer4:
In the profound verse of Surah Al-Qasas (28:61), Allah draws a striking contrast between those anchored in the eternal promise of divine grace and those seduced by fleeting worldly pleasures. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) illuminate this verse as a call to align one’s heart with transcendent realities rather than transient distractions. Imam Ali (AS) states, *"The world is a corpse; whoever seeks it is a dog"* (Ghurar al-Hikam), emphasizing that prioritizing worldly gains over spiritual truths chains the soul to base desires. The "good promise" in the verse, as explained by Imam Sadiq (AS), refers to the covenant of *Wilayah*—the loving devotion to Allah’s chosen guides, the Imams (AS). Those who uphold this covenant are assured Paradise, while those who abandon it for worldly glitter face humiliation on Judgment Day.  

Lady Fatimah (AS) taught that *"the world is a bridge; cross it, do not dwell upon it,"* urging believers to use worldly means as tools for eternal salvation, not as ends in themselves. The verse’s warning against becoming "*among those presented [for punishment]*" underscores the Shia theological principle that rejecting the *Imamah* severs one from divine mercy. Practical wisdom from the Imams directs us to daily renew our allegiance to the Ahlul Bayt through sincere supplications like *Ziyarat Ashura*, acts of charity, and upholding justice even when costly. Imam Baqir (AS) advises: *"Let your mornings and evenings be in preparing for the Hereafter, for death comes without warning."* Thus, this verse becomes a mirror for self-assessment: Are we nurturing our connection to the infinite, or have we mortgaged our souls for temporary comfort? The path of the Ahlul Bayt is one of conscious detachment, where every worldly choice is weighed against its eternal echo.

61.layer5:
In interpreting Quran 28:61, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s core message contrasting eternal divine promises with transient worldly gains. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) alike emphasize the rhetorical force of the comparison, underscoring Quranic warnings against prioritizing material prosperity over spiritual accountability. Ibn Kathir and Al-Tabtabai’s *Al-Mizan* both frame this as a universal ethical principle, urging detachment from temporal comforts in favor of eschatological preparedness. The Qurtubi and Al-Tusi’s *Al-Tibyan* further agree that the “good promise” refers broadly to divine rewards for righteous believers, with Al-Qummi specifying this includes Paradise and proximity to Allah.

Divergences emerge in contextualizing the “promised” individuals. Shia commentaries like *Tafsir al-Qummi* and *Majma al-Bayan* often link the verse’s blessings to allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt, interpreting the “good promise” as encompassing both spiritual rewards and divinely guided leadership. Al-Tabtabai contextualizes this within the Shia paradigm of walaya (divinely ordained guardianship), viewing true believers as those recognizing the Imams’ authority. Conversely, Sunni scholars like Al-Razi in *Mafatih al-Ghayb* and Ibn Kathir avoid such specific political or theological identifications, instead emphasizing general faith and moral conduct as prerequisites for divine fulfillment. Al-Tabari’s analysis historicizes the verse as addressing Quraysh’s elite who opposed Prophet Muhammad, while Al-Qurtubi frames worldly “enjoyment” as a test of gratitude.

These distinctions reflect broader theological frameworks: Shia interpretations often integrate Imamology into Quranic ethics, whereas Sunni exegesis prioritizes communal orthopraxy. Both traditions, however, reinforce the verse’s practical imperative to prioritize eternal consequences over immediate gratification, demonstrating how shared Quranic principles manifest through distinct hermeneutical lenses shaped by historical community formation and doctrinal priorities.

62.layer1:
This verse from Surah al-Qasas presents a powerful scene from the Day of Judgment, where Allah directly addresses those who associated partners with Him (shirk), challenging their false beliefs. The phrase "Where are My 'partners' which you used to claim?" is a rhetorical question exposing the emptiness of idolatry. In Shia tafsir, scholars like Allama Tabatabai explain that this verse underscores Allah’s absolute oneness (tawhid) and the futility of worshipping anything besides Him, whether physical idols, worldly desires, or misguided ideologies. The term *shuraka'i* (partners) refers to false gods or powers humans inventively equate with Allah, a rejection of which lies at the core of Islamic teachings.

Historically, this Meccan verse confronted the polytheistic Quraysh who worshipped idols like Lat and Uzza, but its message transcends time. Shia commentaries link it to rejecting all forms of deviation from divine guidance, including the rejection of the Imams from the Ahlul Bayt, whom Allah appointed as spiritual and moral guides. The "claim" (taz'umun) criticized here implies baseless assertions lacking divine proof, emphasizing that truth is rooted in revelation, not human whims.

Today, this verse calls Muslims to examine what they prioritize over Allah – be it wealth, status, or ideologies contradicting Islamic principles. It reminds us that on Judgment Day, no false "partner" can intercede or answer Allah’s call, urging believers to align their lives with tawhid. Practically, this means centering decisions on Quranic values, seeking rightful guidance through the Prophet’s progeny, and resisting modern forms of shirk like materialism or blind adherence to corrupt systems. By internalizing this verse, Muslims strengthen their accountability to Allah alone, fostering a society anchored in divine truth.
62.layer2:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:62), Allah’s rhetorical question to polytheists on the Day of Judgment—"Where are My ‘partners’ which you used to claim?"—is interpreted by classical Shia exegetes as a profound exposition on divine *tawhid* (oneness) and the nullification of *shirk* (polytheism). Allama Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, emphasizes that this verse encapsulates the principle of divine justice: the disbelievers’ fabricated deities will abandon them, exposing the futility of associating partners (*shuraka'*) with Allah. He explains that such partners—whether idols, worldly powers, or misguided leaders—are mere illusions, incapable of intercession or accountability. This aligns with the Shia theological axiom that true authority (*wilayah*) belongs solely to Allah and His chosen representatives, the Ahlul Bayt.

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, highlights the linguistic force of the term *taz‘umun* ("you used to claim"), underscoring the disbelievers’ delusional assertions against divine reality. Narrations from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq elucidate that the "partners" condemned here extend beyond physical idols to include allegiances to tyrannical rulers or ideologies opposing the Imamah—a core tenet of Shia doctrine. This connects to the broader Shia understanding of *shirk* as not only theological but also socio-political, rejecting any system contradicting the divinely ordained leadership of the Imams.

The verse also underscores the principle of *bara'ah* (disassociation), integral to Shia eschatology, where believers are purified from false associations. Classical commentaries link this to the Quranic theme of accountability in *mizan* (divine scales), where allegiance to Allah’s unity and the Prophet’s household determines eternal fate. Jurisprudentially, this reinforces the obligation to uphold *tawhid* in worship and governance, rejecting all forms of usurped authority. Thus, the verse serves as both a theological indictment of *shirk* and a reaffirmation of the Shia paradigm of divine-guided leadership.
62.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Qasas 62 is often interpreted as a profound critique of modern idolatries—not merely of stone idols, but of ideologies, systems, and obsessions that displace divine sovereignty. Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, emphasizes that the verse’s questioning of “partners” (shuraka) transcends historical polytheism, addressing today’s “hidden shirk”: the elevation of materialism, nationalism, or unchecked technological progress to the status of ultimate concerns. This resonates with philosopher Abdolkarim Soroush’s exploration of how secular modernity often substitutes transcendent purpose with human-centric absolutes, creating societal fragmentation and existential voids.  

Scientifically, the verse invites reflection on humanity’s tendency to attribute causal power to created systems while neglecting the Primary Cause (al-Mubdi’). For instance, breakthroughs in AI or genetic engineering, while awe-inspiring, risk fostering illusions of human omnipotence, echoing the Quranic warning against ascribing partnership to Allah in creativity and control. Socially, scholars like Dr. Reza Shah-Kazemi connect the verse to crises like climate change, where exploitation of nature—a form of shirk by violating humanity’s role as stewards (khalifah)—has led to ecological collapse.  

Interfaith dialogues highlight shared eschatological themes: Christianity’s “judgment seat” or Hindu karma reflect universal accountability, but Islam’s insistence on *tawhid* (oneness) uniquely challenges all forms of reductionism. In multicultural societies, this verse calls for critiquing ideologies that marginalize spiritual humility, urging a recentering on divine unity as the antidote to modern alienation.
62.layer4:
On the Day of Reckoning, Allah's call "Where are My 'partners'?" pierces through the illusions of those who abandoned the path of Tawhid and wilayah. The Ahlul Bayt (as) teach that this divine question transcends literal idolatry, exposing the spiritual betrayal of rejecting Allah’s chosen guides. Imam Ali (as) states in Nahj al-Balagha: "People worship Allah in three ways: some worship Him out of fear – that is slavery; others seek reward – that is mercenary worship; but the true servants worship Him in love – that is the worship of the noble." This verse targets those whose hearts were enslaved by worldly "partners" – pride, hypocrisy, or allegiance to false leaders – while neglecting the Imamah’s luminous guidance.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (as) interprets this verse as addressing those who recognized Allah’s Lordship verbally but rejected "the successors through whom one approaches Him" (al-Kafi). The "partners" symbolize every soul that prioritized human opinions over divine appointment, exchanging the light of Ahlul Bayt (as) for shadows. Lady Fatimah (as) declared in her Fadak sermon: "Allah made obedience to us the framework for community cohesion and our Imamate protection against disunity." To claim love for Allah while disregarding His living Proofs is the hidden shirk this verse condemns.

Practical wisdom flows from anchoring one’s soul in the Ark of Ahlul Bayt (as). Daily renew allegiance through Salat with presence, studying their sermons, and embodying their justice. As Imam Zayn al-Abidin (as) teaches in Sahifa Sajjadiyya: "Make my faith firm through certainty, and my chest open through submission." Let every claimed "partner" – be it ego, materialism, or blind imitation – crumble before the transformative power of loving and obeying the Fourteen Infallibles (as). For on that Day, only those rooted in their guardianship will answer Allah’s call with illuminated hearts.

Both schools emphasize the verse’s eschatological context, interpreting Allah’s questioning of polytheists about their “claimed partners” as a definitive rejection of *shirk* (associating partners with God). Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) concur that this rhetorical interrogation underscores divine oneness (*tawhid*) and the futility of idolatry, with Al-Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* and Ibn Kathir’s *Tafsir* both framing it as a universal warning against spiritual misguidance. Al-Qurtubi (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) similarly stress the verse’s role in affirming accountability, noting its alignment with Quranic descriptions of the hereafter’s inevitability.

Divergences emerge in contextual extensions. Shia commentaries like Al-Qummi’s *Tafsir* and Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan* often link the verse implicitly to the rejection of false leadership, interpreting “claimed partners” as encompassing those who usurped the rights of the Ahl al-Bayt. This reflects the Shia theological emphasis on *imamah* as an extension of divine authority. Sunni scholars such as Al-Razi (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*) avoid this political reading, instead focusing on broader theological *shirk*, including excessive saint veneration or philosophical deviations regarding God’s attributes. 

These differences stem from distinct historical engagements: Shia exegesis developed within narratives of succession and spiritual authority, while Sunni interpretations prioritized creedal unity amid early theological debates. Both traditions, however, utilize this verse to reinforce monotheistic practice—Shia communities emphasizing loyalty to divinely appointed guides, and Sunni scholars cautioning against innovations in worship. The shared ethical imperative remains: rejecting all forms of idolatry, whether tangible or conceptual, to uphold pure devotion to Allah.

63.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qasas verse 63, Allah depicts a scene from the Day of Judgment where misguided leaders and influencers will desperately distance themselves from those they led astray. The phrase *haqqa ‘alayhimu al-qawl* (“those upon whom the word will have come into effect”) refers to individuals whose eternal fate is sealed due to their persistent rejection of truth. They cry out, *rabbana haula’i alladhina aghwayna* (“Our Lord, these are the ones we led to error”), acknowledging their role in corrupting others, yet they confess they were themselves lost (*kama ghawayna* – “as we were in error”). The word *aghwayna* derives from *ghawa*, meaning to stray into darkness, highlighting how misguidance perpetuates spiritual blindness. Their declaration *tabarra’na ilayk* (“We disassociate ourselves [from them] to You”) reflects a futile attempt to evade accountability, revealing the breakdown of false hierarchies and loyalties in the hereafter. Crucially, they admit *ma kanu iyyana ya’budun* (“they did not worship us”), underscoring that blind followers ultimately worshipped their own desires, not the leaders themselves.

This verse, revealed in Mecca, critiques the arrogance of Qurayshi elites who mocked Islam while coercing others to reject it. Shia tafsir, such as Allamah Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, links this to the broader Quranic theme of *tabarra* – disassociating from oppressors and corrupt influencers. The verse warns against blindly following societal or religious authorities who prioritize power over divine truth. In modern contexts, this calls Muslims to critically evaluate leaders, ideologies, and trends that promote materialism, injustice, or deviation from Quranic values. It reminds us that spiritual responsibility is personal; we cannot blame others for our choices. The Shia emphasis on aligning with the *Ahlul Bayt* – the Prophet’s purified progeny – as guides against misguidance becomes a practical application: seek knowledge, uphold moral autonomy, and reject systems that normalize sin or oppression. Ultimately, the verse urges self-accountability and conscious adherence to divine guidance over the fleeting approval of misguided influencers.
63.layer2:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:63), the Qur’an depicts a profound scene of reciprocal disavowal between misguided leaders and their followers on the Day of Judgment. Classical Shia exegetes, such as Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Shaykh Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, elucidate this verse through theological and ethical frameworks central to Shia thought. The “word” (qawl) that “comes into effect” is interpreted as the divine decree of punishment resulting from persistent rejection of truth, a concept tied to the Shia understanding of *qada* (predetermined divine will) and *qadar* (divine measure). Tabatabai emphasizes that these leaders, symbolized by Pharaoh and his elites, represent those who actively opposed divine guidance and misled others, thereby sealing their fate through conscious rebellion (Al-Mizan 16:64).

Tabrisi notes that their confession—“We led them to error just as we were in error”—reveals a belated acknowledgment of moral responsibility, underscoring the Shia principle of *ikhtiyar* (free will) and accountability. The mutual rejection (“they did not used to worship us”) highlights the futility of worldly hierarchies in the hereafter, where neither leaders nor followers can absolve themselves. This aligns with the Shia theological tenet that ultimate allegiance belongs solely to Allah, and any deviation from the *Ahlul Bayt*’s guidance constitutes spiritual betrayal. 

The verse also resonates with the Shia doctrine of *imamah*, wherein rightful leaders guide humanity to divine truth, while false claimants propagate misguidance. The disavowal scene serves as a caution against blind allegiance to illegitimate authority, reinforcing the ethical duty to uphold *wilayah* (guardianship of the Imams). Both commentators stress divine justice (*adl*) in holding individuals accountable for their choices, rejecting the notion of collective punishment without personal agency. This interplay of divine decree, human responsibility, and the consequences of rejecting true guidance forms a cornerstone of Shia eschatology and moral philosophy.
63.layer3:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:63), the Quran paints a haunting scene where misguided leaders in the afterlife disown their followers, revealing the moral bankruptcy of exploiting human vulnerability. Contemporary Shia scholars, like Ayatollah Naser Makarem Shirazi, emphasize this verse as a caution against the *spiritual responsibility of influence*—particularly relevant in an age of digital misinformation and ideological polarization. Leaders, whether political, religious, or cultural, are reminded that their authority isn’t a license to manipulate but a trust (amana) requiring ethical stewardship.  

Modern scholars such as Dr. Liyakat Takim highlight how the verse critiques systemic oppression, linking it to today’s social justice struggles. For instance, industries profiting from environmental destruction or politicians weaponizing xenophobia mirror the “leading into error” described—exploiting fear or ignorance for power. Philosophically, this resonates with Hannah Arendt’s “banality of evil,” where ordinary people enable harm through uncritical compliance.  

Scientifically, cognitive studies on groupthink and confirmation bias explain why followers often internalize toxic ideologies. Social media algorithms, which amplify divisive content, act as modern-day “misleaders,” creating echo chambers that fracture communities. The verse’s interfaith relevance is clear: Christianity’s warning against “false prophets” and Buddhist teachings on right speech parallel Islam’s call to reject manipulative rhetoric.  

In our interconnected world, this verse urges a multicultural ethics of accountability. Whether addressing climate denial, hate speech, or economic injustice, it challenges both leaders and followers to interrogate whose “word” they’re perpetuating—and whether it aligns with divine justice or worldly corruption. In Surah Al-Qasas verse 63, the misguided leaders of falsehood disown their followers on the Day of Judgment, exposing the tragic end of those who abandoned divine guidance. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) illuminate the spiritual dimensions of this verse, emphasizing that true salvation lies in recognising and submitting to the *Wilayah* (divinely ordained authority) of Allah’s chosen guides. Imam Muhammad al-Baqir (peace be upon him) states, "The verse refers to those who rejected the Imams of their time and instead followed leaders of misguidance. On Judgment Day, these false leaders will declare their innocence from those they misled, just as Pharaoh’s chiefs disowned their followers." This underscores the Shia principle that rejecting the Imamah plunges societies into mutual misguidance.

The verse warns against blind allegiance to worldly powers usurping spiritual authority. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) taught, "The one who takes a leader without Allah’s command becomes an idol worshipped besides Him." Here, "worship" transcends rituals; it signifies inner submission. True worship necessitates aligning one's heart and actions with the divine criteria embodied by the Ahlul Bayt. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) echoes this in her famed sermon: "Follow the Imams of truth, for they are the ship of salvation in the stormy seas of misguidance."

Practically, this verse urges believers to critically assess whom they emulate. Spiritual development depends on grounding one’s loyalties in the *Ma’rifah* (recognition) of the Imams. As Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) advised, "Seek knowledge that illuminates the heart—the knowledge of the Imam’s rights." Regular supplications like *Dua al-Iftitah*, which invokes the Imam's guidance, and reflecting on the *Ziyarat of Imam Husayn* (peace be upon him), which condemns oppressors while affirming loyalty to truth, fortify this awareness. Ultimately, the verse calls for sincere repentance, conscious detachment from falsehood, and unwavering adherence to the luminous path of the Ahlul Bayt.
