In interpreting Quran 28:63, both Shia and Sunni scholars converge on its eschatological context depicting disbelievers' mutual recriminations on Judgment Day. Tabatabai (Al-Mizan) and Ibn Kathir agree the verse exposes how misguided leaders bear responsibility for corrupting followers, emphasizing Islam's rejection of blind obedience to false authorities. Qurtubi and Tabrisi (Majma al-Bayan) both highlight the linguistic emphasis on "aghwaynahum" (we led them astray), underscoring shared theological principles about accountability for moral corruption.

Divergences emerge in identifying the "those upon whom the word has come into effect." Sunni exegetes like Tabari and Razi (Mafatih al-Ghayb) generally interpret this as generic leaders of disbelief, with Ibn Kathir citing Pharaoh’s chiefs as prototypes. Shia sources, particularly Tusi (At-Tibyan) and Qummi, often contextualize this through the lens of wilaya (divinely appointed leadership), interpreting the "misleaders" as those rejecting the Ahl al-Bayt’s guidance. Tabatabai extends this to encompass all usurpers of rightful spiritual authority across history.

Theological foundations differ regarding human agency: Razi’s Sunni analysis stresses individual choice in following misguidance, while Shia commentaries like Majma al-Bayan emphasize systemic corruption when divinely appointed leadership is opposed. These interpretations influence religious practice subtly - Sunni discourses often caution against uncritical adherence to scholars or rulers, whereas Shia teachings reinforce allegiance to the Imams as safeguards against misguidance.

Historically, these differences stem from distinct epistemological approaches. Sunni tafsir developed alongside debates about political leadership and theological voluntarism, while Shia exegesis evolved through preserving the Imams’ interpretive legacy. Both traditions nevertheless unite in using this verse to warn against spiritual negligence and promote ethical responsibility in communal leadership.

64.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qasas, verse 64, Allah paints a vivid scene from the Day of Judgment, where those who worshipped false deities alongside Him are confronted with the futility of their beliefs. The verse begins with a command: *“Invoke your ‘partners’*” (*shuraka’akum*), referring to the imaginary gods or worldly attachments people elevated to divine status. The polytheists will desperately call upon these false deities, but they will receive no response (*lam yastajibu lahum*), leaving them helpless as they face the reality of divine punishment (*ra’aw al-adhab*). The verse closes with a poignant reflection: *“If only they had followed guidance!”*—a lament for their rejection of truth and monotheism.

This verse, revealed in Mecca, directly challenged the Quraysh’s idolatry, exposing the emptiness of their rituals and the false security of their man-made gods. The Arabic term *shuraka’* (partners) underscores the core Islamic principle of *Tawhid*—Allah’s absolute oneness—and rejects *shirk* (associating partners with Him), the gravest sin in Islam. Historically, this verse reassured early Muslims facing persecution, affirming that temporal power structures and false idols would ultimately crumble.

For contemporary Muslims, this verse is a timeless warning against modern forms of *shirk*: prioritizing wealth, status, or ideologies over divine truth. It calls believers to critically assess what they “worship” in practice—be it materialism, ego, or blind adherence to cultural norms—and to recenter their lives on Allah alone. The phrase *“If only they had followed guidance”* serves as a motivator to seek knowledge, uphold *Tawhid*, and align actions with the Quran and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, who exemplify true devotion. By internalizing this message, Muslims can cultivate resilience against spiritual distractions and build lives rooted in purposeful faith.
64.layer2:
In classical Shia exegesis, Surah Al-Qasas 64 is interpreted as a profound indictment of *shirk* (polytheism) and misguidance, emphasizing the futility of relying on false deities or illegitimate authorities in the face of divine judgment. The verse’s command to “invoke your partners” is understood by scholars like Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* as a divine exposure of the disbelievers’ spiritual bankruptcy on the Day of Resurrection. Tabatabai explains that the “partners” (*shuraka’*) symbolize all false objects of devotion—whether idols, tyrannical rulers, or self-appointed religious leaders—who usurped the exclusive right of Allah to lordship and guidance. Their inability to respond underscores the absolute dependence of creation on the true source of authority: Allah and His designated guides.

Shia commentators, including Al-Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan*, link this verse to the theological principle of *wilayah* (divine guardianship), asserting that true guidance is inseparable from allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt. The phrase “If only they had followed guidance” is seen as an allusion to the rejection of the Imams, whom Shia tradition regards as the sole interpreters of divine revelation and intermediaries of mercy. Tabrisi notes that the disbelievers’ realization of their error upon witnessing punishment reflects the irreversible consequences of abandoning the “straight path” upheld by the Prophet’s household.

The verse also resonates with Shia eschatology, where intercession (*shafa’a*) is reserved for those who upheld *tawhid* (divine unity) and recognized the rights of the Ahl al-Bayt. The failed invocation of false partners thus becomes a stark contrast to the believer’s reliance on the Imams’ spiritual mediation. This aligns with Imam Jafar al-Sadiq’s teachings, cited in classical sources, which stress that guidance is not merely intellectual assent but unwavering adherence to the divinely appointed successors of the Prophet. In jurisprudence, the verse reinforces the obligation to reject all forms of illegitimate authority and uphold the ontological hierarchy established by Allah, where the Ahl al-Bayt are the custodians of divine wisdom and mercy.
64.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Qasas 28:64 is often interpreted as a profound critique of modern ideological "partnerships" that displace divine sovereignty. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his exegesis, emphasizes that the verse transcends literal polytheism, addressing any force—materialism, unchecked capitalism, or authoritarianism—that humans elevate as rivals to God’s authority. Scholar Dr. Mohammad Shomali, in recent lectures, connects this to the "idolatry of data," where algorithms and social media platforms command obsessive loyalty, fragmenting moral focus—a digital-age echo of the verse’s warning about false intermediaries.  

Philosophically, the failed invocation of "partners" mirrors what sociologist Hartmut Rosa calls "resonance crisis": modernity’s paradox of hyper-connection yielding profound disconnection. The verse’s imagery of unanswered cries parallels climate activists’ pleas to industries fixated on profit, or marginalized communities seeking justice in systems rigged against them. Neuroscientific studies on addiction (cited by ethicist Dr. Ahmed Al-Shahristani) reveal how dopamine-driven pursuits—wealth, fame—create false "gods" that, like the verse’s partners, offer transient highs but eternal void.  

Interfaith dialogues, such as those led by the Imam Hussein Islamic Center in London, frame this verse as a universal call to audit societal priorities: Buddhist teachings on detachment, Christian critiques of Mammon, and Indigenous worldviews rejecting ecological exploitation all resonate here. For Shia communities, the "guidance" mentioned becomes a mandate to center the Qur’an and Ahlul Bayt’s justice-oriented legacy in addressing crises like AI ethics or refugee rights—reminding us that true tawhid (oneness) demands dismantling every hierarchy that obscures the Divine.
64.layer4:
In Surah Al-Qasas verse 64, Allah unveils a profound scene from the Day of Judgment, where those who worshipped false "partners" alongside Him are commanded to call upon them for help—only to face utter abandonment. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) teach that this verse transcends literal idol worship, exposing the spiritual bankruptcy of all forms of *shirk* (associating partners with Allah), including the rejection of divine guidance through the Imams. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) states in *Tafsir al-Qummi*: "On that Day, the leaders of misguidance and their followers will realize their mutual betrayal. The Imams of truth will stand as witnesses against them, for they were the manifest ropes of Allah’s Wilayah."

The "partners" denounced here symbolize any force—worldly desires, tyrannical rulers, or arrogant scholars—that distracts hearts from the *Noor* (light) of the Ahlul Bayt. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) declared in her famed sermon: "You turned away from the *Hujjah* (divine proof) and chose the glitter of ephemeral life." The verse’s closing lament, *"If only they had followed guidance!"* echoes the Prophet’s (peace be upon him and his family) declaration at Ghadir: "Whoever I am his Mawla, Ali is his Mawla." True guidance is inseparable from unwavering allegiance (*Tawalli*) to the Imams and distancing (*Tabarri*) from their enemies.

Practically, this verse calls believers to audit their loyalties daily: Do we prioritize the transient "partners" of ego, materialism, or societal approval over the eternal Wilayah of Ali and his purified progeny? Imam Ali (peace be upon him) advises: "Bind your heart to the *Hujjah* who is never absent from creation, for he is the rope between Allah and His slaves." By nurturing love for the Ahlul Bayt, studying their teachings, and aligning actions with their Sunnah, we anchor ourselves to the Ark of Salvation, ensuring that on the Day of Regret, we are among those who followed the *Sirat al-Mustaqim* through the door of Imamah.

شیعہ مبصرین ، بشمول *مجمہ البیان *میں الاترسی ، اس آیت کو *ولیہ *(الہی سرپرستی) کے مذہبی اصول سے جوڑتے ہیں ، اور یہ کہتے ہوئے کہ اے ایچ ایل البیٹ سے بیعت کرنے سے حقیقی رہنمائی لازم و ملزوم ہے۔ "اگر صرف ان کی رہنمائی کی پیروی ہوتی" کے فقرے کو اماموں کے مسترد ہونے کے اشارے کے طور پر دیکھا جاتا ہے ، جسے شیعہ روایت الہی وحی اور رحمت کے بیچوانوں کے واحد ترجمان کی حیثیت سے دیکھتے ہیں۔ تبریسی نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ کافروں نے سزا سنانے پر ان کی غلطی کا ادراک نبی کے گھر والے کے ذریعہ "سیدھے راستے" کو ترک کرنے کے ناقابل واپسی نتائج کی عکاسی کی ہے۔

یہ آیت شیعہ ایسکیٹولوجی سے بھی گونجتی ہے ، جہاں شفاعت (*شافا*) ان لوگوں کے لئے مخصوص ہے جنہوں نے*توہید*(الہی اتحاد) کو برقرار رکھا اور اے ایچ ایل البیٹ کے حقوق کو تسلیم کیا۔ اس طرح جھوٹے شراکت داروں کی ناکام دعوت نامے کے نام سے مومن کی روحانی ثالثی پر انحصار کا بالکل برعکس بن جاتا ہے۔ اس سے امام جعفر السادق کی تعلیمات کے مطابق ہے ، جس کا حوالہ کلاسیکی ذرائع میں ہے ، جس پر زور دیا گیا ہے کہ رہنمائی محض فکری رضامندی نہیں ہے بلکہ نبی of کے خدائی مقرر کردہ جانشینوں کی پابندی ہے۔ فقہ میں ، آیت اس کی ذمہ داری کو تقویت بخشتی ہے کہ وہ غیر قانونی اختیار کی ہر شکل کو مسترد کرے اور اللہ کے ذریعہ قائم کردہ آنٹولوجیکل درجہ بندی کو برقرار رکھے ، جہاں اہل البیت الہی حکمت اور رحمت کے متولی ہیں۔

فلسفیانہ طور پر ، "شراکت داروں" کی ناکام درخواست کی آئینہ دار ہے جس کو ماہر معاشیات ہارٹمٹ روزا "گونج بحران" کہتے ہیں: جدیدیت کا ہائپر کنکشن کا تضاد ہے جس سے گہرا منقطع ہوتا ہے۔ غیر جوابدہ چیخوں کی آیت کی منظر کشی آب و ہوا کے کارکنوں کی متوازی ہے جو منافع پر قائم صنعتوں ، یا پسماندہ طبقات کے لئے انصاف کے حصول کے لئے پسماندہ طبقات کی التجا کرتی ہے۔ نشے کے بارے میں اعصابی مطالعات (اخلاقیات کے ذریعہ پیش کردہ ڈاکٹر احمد الشہرستانی) سے یہ ظاہر ہوتا ہے کہ کس طرح ڈوپامائن سے چلنے والے تعاقب-ویلتھ ، شہرت-جھوٹے "دیوتاؤں" کو تخلیق کرتے ہیں جو آیت کے شراکت داروں کی طرح عارضی اونچائی نہیں کرتے ہیں۔  

بین المذاہب مکالمے ، جیسے لندن میں امام حسین اسلامک سنٹر کی سربراہی میں ، اس آیت کو آڈٹ معاشرتی ترجیحات کے آڈٹ کے طور پر پیش کرتے ہیں: لاتعلقی سے متعلق بدھ مت کی تعلیمات ، میمون کے عیسائی تنقید ، اور مقامی نظریات کو یہاں سے گونجنے والے ماحولیاتی استحصال کو مسترد کرتے ہیں۔ شیعہ کمیونٹیز کے لئے ، ذکر کردہ "رہنمائی" قرآن مجید اور اہل بیت کی انصاف پر مبنی میراث کو اے اخلاقیات یا مہاجرین کے حقوق جیسے بحرانوں سے نمٹنے کے لئے ایک مینڈیٹ بن جاتی ہے۔ یہ ہمیں یہ قرار دیتے ہیں کہ سچے طواد (وحدانیت) نے ہر اس درجہ بندی کو ختم کرنے کا مطالبہ کیا ہے جو اس خدائی کو مبہم کرتا ہے۔

یہاں "شراکت داروں" کی مذمت کی گئی ہے کہ وہ کسی بھی قوت کی علامت ہے - دنیا کی خواہشات ، ظالم حکمران ، یا متکبر اسکالرز - جو اہل بائٹ کے * نور * (روشنی) سے دلوں کو دور کرتی ہے۔ لیڈی فاطمہ (ان پر امن) نے اپنے مشہور خطبہ میں اعلان کیا: "آپ * ہجاہ * (خدائی ثبوت) سے منہ موڑ گئے اور اس نے حقیقت پسندی کی زندگی کا انتخاب کیا۔" آیت کا بند ہونے والا نوحہ ، * "اگر صرف وہ رہنمائی پر عمل کرتے!" حقیقی رہنمائی غیر متزلزل بیعت (*تووالی*) سے لازم و ملزوم ہے جو ان کے دشمنوں سے اماموں اور دور (*تباری*) سے دور ہے۔

64.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Qasas 64, Shia and Sunni scholars converge on its core eschatological theme: the futility of polytheism and the inevitability of divine accountability. Both traditions, as reflected in Tabari’s *Jami al-Bayan* and Tabatabai’s *Al-Mizan*, emphasize the verse’s condemnation of *shirk* (idolatry), underscoring that false deities will abandon their devotees on Judgment Day. Ibn Kathir and Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan* similarly highlight the psychological torment of disbelievers realizing their misguidance, framing the verse as a universal warning against spiritual misdirection. The Qurtubi and Tusi’s *At-Tibyan* both stress the theological principle that only Allah’s guidance—rooted in monotheism and prophetic teachings—offers salvation.

Divergent interpretations emerge in contextualizing the “partners” (*shuraka*) invoked. Sunni exegetes like Razi in *Mafatih al-Ghayb* often limit this to pre-Islamic Arab idolatry, interpreting the verse historically as a critique of pagan practices. Shia commentaries, particularly Qummi’s *Tafsir al-Qummi*, extend the metaphor to include illegitimate leadership opposing the Ahlul Bayt, reflecting the doctrine of *Imamah*. Tabatabai argues that the verse implicitly critiques those who reject divinely appointed guides, tying true “guidance” to allegiance to the Imams. This divergence stems from Shia theology’s emphasis on the Imam’s role as the spiritual and interpretive heir of the Prophet, a concept less central in Sunni hermeneutics.

These differences influence religious perspectives on authority and continuity of guidance. Sunni readings reinforce vigilance against *shirk* in worship, while Shia interpretations integrate the verse into discourses on legitimate leadership. Historically, these distinctions arose from early Islamic debates over succession and religious authority, with Shia exegesis evolving within frameworks prioritizing the Ahlul Bayt’s legacy. Both traditions, however, unite in using the verse to affirm tawhid and the consequences of deviating from divine truth.

سورہ القاساس 64 کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ، شیعہ اور سنی اسکالرز اس کے بنیادی اسکیٹولوجیکل تھیم پر ایک دوسرے کے ساتھ مل جاتے ہیں: کثیر الجہتی کی فضولیت اور خدائی احتساب کی ناگزیر۔ دونوں روایات ، جیسا کہ تباری کے *جامی البیان *اور تبتابائی کے *المزان *میں عکاسی ہوتی ہے ، اس آیت کی *شرک *(بت پرستی) کی مذمت پر زور دیتی ہے ، اس بات پر زور دیتے ہوئے کہ فیصلے کے دن جھوٹے دیوتا اپنے عقیدت مندوں کو ترک کردیں گے۔ ابن کتھیر اور تبریسی کے * مجمہ البیان * اسی طرح کافروں کے نفسیاتی عذاب کو اجاگر کرتے ہیں جو ان کی غلط فہمی کا ادراک کرتے ہیں ، اور اس آیت کو روحانی غلط سمت کے خلاف ایک آفاقی انتباہ کے طور پر تشکیل دیتے ہیں۔ قربانی اور توسی کے * ایٹ تبیان * دونوں ہی مذہبی اصول پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ صرف اللہ کی رہنمائی-توحید اور پیشن گوئی کی تعلیمات میں جکڑی ہوئی ہے۔

متنازعہ تشریحات "شراکت داروں" (*شوراکا*) کو سیاق و سباق میں لانے میں ابھرتی ہیں۔ * مافاتیہ الغیب * میں ریزی کی طرح سنی کی منظوری اکثر اس کو اسلامی عرب بت پرستی تک محدود کرتی ہے ، اور اس آیت کو تاریخی طور پر کافر طریقوں کی تنقید کے طور پر ترجمانی کرتی ہے۔ شیعہ کی تفسیر ، خاص طور پر قمی کے *طافسیر القومی *، استعارے کو بڑھا دیتے ہیں تاکہ اہل بیت کی مخالفت کرنے والی ناجائز قیادت کو شامل کیا جاسکے ، جس میں *امامہ *کے نظریے کی عکاسی ہوتی ہے۔ تبتابائی نے استدلال کیا کہ آیت واضح طور پر ان لوگوں پر تنقید کرتی ہے جنہوں نے خدائی طور پر مقرر کردہ ہدایت نامہ کو مسترد کرتے ہوئے ، اماموں سے بیعت کرنے کے لئے حقیقی "رہنمائی" باندھ دی۔ یہ موڑ شیعہ الہیات کے نبی of کے روحانی اور تشریحی وارث کی حیثیت سے امام کے کردار پر زور دینے سے پیدا ہوتا ہے ، جو سنی ہرمینیٹکس میں کم مرکزی خیال ہے۔

یہ اختلافات اتھارٹی اور رہنمائی کے تسلسل پر مذہبی نقطہ نظر کو متاثر کرتے ہیں۔ سنی ریڈنگز عبادت میں * شرک * کے خلاف چوکسی کو تقویت دیتی ہے ، جبکہ شیعہ تشریحات آیت کو جائز قیادت پر گفتگو میں ضم کرتی ہیں۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ امتیازات جانشینی اور مذہبی اتھارٹی کے بارے میں ابتدائی اسلامی مباحثوں سے پیدا ہوئے ، شیعہ نے احل بائٹ کی میراث کو ترجیح دینے والے فریم ورک کے اندر تیار کیا۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات توہد کی تصدیق کرنے کے لئے آیت کو استعمال کرنے میں متحد ہوجاتی ہیں اور خدائی سچائی سے انحراف کے نتائج۔
64.layer2short: In classical Shia exegesis, Surah Al-Qasas 64 is interpreted as a profound indictment of *shirk* (polytheism) and misguidance, emphasizing the futility of relying on false deities or illegitimate authorities in the face of divine judgment. The verse’s command to “invoke your partners” is understood by scholars like Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* as a divine exposure of the disbelievers’ spiritual bankruptcy on the Day of Resurrection. Tabatabai explains that the “partners” (*shuraka’*) symbolize all false objects of devotion—whether idols, tyrannical rulers, or self-appointed religious leaders—who usurped the exclusive right of Allah to lordship and guidance. Their inability to respond underscores the absolute dependence of creation on the true source of authority: Allah and His designated guides.

65.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qasas verse 65, Allah describes a profound moment on the Day of Judgment when He will directly question humanity: *"What did you answer the messengers?"* This verse underscores the eternal principle of divine accountability, emphasizing that every soul will be asked about their response to the guidance brought by Allah’s chosen messengers. The Arabic phrase *"ajabtum al-mursaleen"* (your response to the messengers) carries layered meaning—it refers not merely to verbal replies but to one’s acceptance or rejection of prophetic teachings in belief, action, and moral conduct. The *"nida"* (call) mentioned here symbolizes Allah’s authority as the ultimate Judge, invoking both justice and mercy, as He gives humanity the chance to reflect on their choices.

While the verse addresses the broader theme of prophethood, Shia tafsir traditions, such as those in *Tafsir al-Mizan* by Allama Tabatabai, link this accountability to the continuity of divine guidance through the *Ahlul Bayt*. Historical narrations from Imams like Ali ibn Abi Talib and Jaafar al-Sadiq explain that rejecting or neglecting the teachings of the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and his purified successors constitutes a failure to "answer the messengers." This verse, revealed in Mecca during intense opposition to the Prophet, served as a warning to those who dismissed his message—a reminder that denial has eternal consequences.

For modern Muslims, this verse calls for self-reflection: Are we living by the moral and spiritual principles taught by the Prophet and his family? In an era of distractions and moral ambiguity, "answering the messengers" means embodying Quranic values—justice, compassion, and integrity—while actively seeking and upholding the truth as preserved by the Ahlul Bayt. It reminds us that our choices today shape our eternal destiny, urging humility and sincerity in following divine guidance.
65.layer2:
In Surah al-Qasas verse 65, Allah’s questioning of humanity on the Day of Resurrection — "What did you answer the messengers?" — is interpreted by classical Shia scholars as a profound examination of humankind’s accountability in responding to divine guidance. Both Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasize that this verse transcends mere historical inquiry into past communities’ responses to prophets; it encapsulates the universal principle of human responsibility toward God’s appointed guides in every era. 

Tabrisi notes that the verse’s phrasing ("What did you answer") implies a holistic evaluation of obedience, rejection, or neglect of the messengers’ teachings, stressing that divine justice necessitates this interrogation. Tabatabai expands this concept within the Shia theological framework, asserting that the "messengers" (al-mursalin) encompass not only prophets but also the Imams from the Ahl al-Bayt, who are regarded as inheritors and protectors of prophetic mission. This aligns with the Shia doctrine of *wisayah* (succession), which holds that Imam Ali and his descendants are divinely designated guides, ensuring the continuity of prophetic truth. Their teachings, like those of prophets, demand adherence as part of one’s covenant with God.

The verse also invokes the Shia concept of *hujjah* (divine proof), wherein rejection of the Imams — as living authorities — constitutes a failure to answer God’s call, with eschatological consequences. Classical commentaries link this to the broader jurisprudential principle that recognizing and obeying the rightful Imam is inseparable from Islamic doctrine, as articulated in traditions from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq. Thus, the verse underscores the inseparable unity of prophetic and Imamate guidance, reinforcing the Shia worldview that salvation hinges on acknowledging both. The questioning on Judgment Day, therefore, becomes a moment of ultimate truth, exposing the sincerity or hypocrisy of one’s acceptance of divine authority in all its forms.
65.layer3:
Contemporary Shia scholarship interprets Surah Al-Qasas 28:65 as a profound call to ethical accountability, extending beyond literal messengers to encompass humanity’s responsibility toward divine guidance in all forms. Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi, in his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, frames the verse as demanding self-reflection: “The ‘messengers’ include both prophets and the universal signs embedded in creation and conscience.” This aligns with thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, who bridges classical exegesis and modern ethics, arguing that responding to “messengers” today means engaging with moral imperatives such as environmental stewardship, social justice, and technological ethics.  

The verse’s interrogation—“What did you answer the messengers?”—resonates with contemporary challenges. Climate activists like Greta Thunberg are framed by scholars such as Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari as modern “bearers of truth,” urging societies to heed ecological warnings as divine warnings (ayat). Philosophically, this evokes Emmanuel Lévinas’ concept of the “Face of the Other,” where responding to human and environmental suffering becomes a theological duty.  

In multicultural contexts, the verse invites interfaith solidarity. Shia jurist Sayyid Fadhil Milani highlights parallels with Jewish *tikkun olam* (world repair) and Christian liberation theology, urging joint action against systemic poverty or displacement crises. The rise of AI and digital misinformation adds urgency: scholars like Dr. Liyakat Takim connect the verse to resisting algorithmic bias and “answering” truth in an age of viral falsehoods.  

Ultimately, this verse challenges modern believers to recognize “messengers” in scientific data, marginalized voices, and interreligious wisdom—a dynamic interplay of revelation, reason, and collective responsibility. As technology and globalization intensify ethical dilemmas, the question of how we “answer” transcends time, binding sacred duty to planetary survival.
65.layer4:
On the Day of Judgment, humanity will face the ultimate accountability: "What did you answer the messengers?" (28:65). The Ahlul Bayt (عليهم السلام) teach that this divine question transcends mere historical response to prophets; it encompasses recognizing and submitting to the *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) of the successors of prophethood—the Imams. Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (عليه السلام) states, *"Every age has a messenger from us, a proof (hujjah) for us over creation. The messenger of this age is the Imam, whose obedience is obligatory."* (Bihar al-Anwar) Thus, responding to "the messengers" includes affirming the Imam of one’s time as the living manifestation of divine guidance.  

Lady Fatimah (عليها السلام) emphasized in her renowned sermon: *"Allah made obedience to us the system for the ummah and our leadership a safeguard against disunity."* This verse, therefore, warns against neglecting the *Imamah*—the seamless spiritual authority flowing from Prophet Muhammad (صلى الله عليه وآله) through the Twelve Imams. To "answer the messengers" is to uphold the covenant of loyalty to the Ahlul Bayt, whose teachings illuminate the straight path.  

Practically, this demands self-accountability (*muhasabah*): Do our actions align with the Imams’ moral and spiritual legacy? Are we striving to internalize their virtues—justice, sincerity, and detachment from worldly illusion—as taught by Imam Ali (عليه السلام)? Spiritual development hinges on recognizing the Imam’s presence as a perpetual mercy, seeking nearness through adherence to their Sunnah, supplications like Ziyarat Ashura, and nurturing love for them. The verse thus becomes a timeless call to awaken the heart to the reality of divine guidance, embodied in the purified progeny of the Prophet (صلى الله عليه وآله)

لیڈی فاطمہ (علیہا السلام) نے اپنے مشہور خطبہ میں زور دیا: "اللہ نے امت اور ہماری قیادت کے لئے ہمارے نظام کی اطاعت کی۔ بارہ امام۔ "میسینجرز کا جواب دینا" اہل بیت کے ساتھ وفاداری کے عہد کو برقرار رکھنا ہے ، جس کی تعلیمات سیدھے راستے کو روشن کرتی ہیں۔  

عملی طور پر ، یہ خود حساب کتاب (*محسابہ*) کا مطالبہ کرتا ہے: کیا ہمارے اعمال اماموں کی اخلاقی اور روحانی میراث کے ساتھ ہم آہنگ ہیں؟ کیا ہم ان کی خوبیوں کو اندرونی بنانے کے لئے کوشاں ہیں - عین مطابق ، اخلاص ، اور دنیاوی وہم سے لاتعلقی - جیسا کہ امام علی (علیہ السلام) نے پڑھایا ہے؟ روحانی نشوونما امام کی موجودگی کو مستقل رحمت کے طور پر تسلیم کرنے ، ان کے سنت پر عمل پیرا ہونے ، زیارت آشورا جیسے التواء کی فراہمی ، اور ان کے لئے محبت کی پرورش کرنے پر منحصر ہے۔ اس طرح آیت ایک بے وقت کال بن جاتی ہے تاکہ دل کو الہی رہنمائی کی حقیقت سے بیدار کیا جاسکے ، جو نبی of کی پاکیزہ اولاد میں مجسم ہے (اللى اللہ علی ع وِلغ)
65.layer5:
The verse’s interrogation on responding to divine messengers elicits rich theological reflection across traditions. Both Shia and Sunni exegetes concur that the verse underscores humanity’s accountability for accepting or rejecting prophetic guidance. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) alike stress its eschatological gravity, framing it as a universal reckoning where all generations are questioned about their response to messengers sent to them (*Jami al-Bayan*; *Majma al-Bayan*). Ibn Kathir and Al-Tusi similarly emphasize the necessity of heeding prophets as bearers of divine truth, with Al-Qurtubi adding that rejection constitutes a denial of God’s mercy (*Al-Jami li-Ahkam*; *Al-Tibyan*).  

A key divergence arises in defining the scope of “messengers” (*mursalin*). Sunni commentators like Al-Razi limit the term to prophets, stressing the finality of Muhammad’s message (*Mafatih al-Ghayb*). In contrast, Shia scholars such as Al-Qummi and Tabatabai extend its application to include the Imams, whom they regard as inheritors of prophetic wisdom (*Tafsir al-Qummi*; *Al-Mizan*). This reflects the Shia theological principle of *imamah* as a continuation of divine guidance, whereas Sunni exegesis prioritizes the closure of revelation with Muhammad.  

These interpretations influence religious practice: Sunni emphasis on prophetic finality reinforces adherence to the Quran and Sunnah as transmitted through companions, while Shia communities integrate devotion to the Imams into their understanding of spiritual obedience. Historically, these differences stem from early debates over leadership and authority after the Prophet’s death, with Shia hermeneutics evolving to address perceived gaps in guidance through the lens of the Ahl al-Bayt’s sanctity.  

Both traditions, however, unite in viewing the verse as a moral imperative to recognize divine truth. As Tabatabai notes, the interrogation transcends sectarian divides, reminding all believers of their duty to pursue righteousness through God’s chosen guides (*Al-Mizan*). Such convergences and divergences illustrate Islam’s dynamic interpretive tradition, rooted in shared reverence for revelation while accommodating theological diversity.
65.layer5_urdu:
الہی میسینجرز کے جواب دینے کے بارے میں آیت کی تفتیش روایات میں بھرپور مذہبی عکاسی کا اظہار کرتی ہے۔ شیعہ اور سنی دونوں نے اس بات پر اتفاق کیا ہے کہ آیت کی پیشن گوئی کی رہنمائی کو قبول کرنے یا مسترد کرنے کے لئے انسانیت کے احتساب کی نشاندہی کی گئی ہے۔ التباری (سنی) اور الاتبریسی (شیعہ) یکساں طور پر اس کی اسکیٹولوجیکل کشش ثقل پر زور دیتے ہیں ، اور اسے ایک آفاقی حساب کے طور پر تیار کرتے ہیں جہاں تمام نسلوں کو ان کے بھیجے جانے والے میسینجرز کے ردعمل کے بارے میں پوچھ گچھ کی جاتی ہے (*جمی البیان*؛*ماجما البیان*)۔ ابن کتھیر اور التوسی اسی طرح نبیوں کو خدائی سچائی کے حامل ہونے کی حیثیت سے دھیان دینے کی ضرورت پر زور دیتے ہیں ، اس کے ساتھ ہی القوروبی نے مزید کہا کہ مسترد ہونے سے خدا کی رحمت سے انکار ہوتا ہے (*الجامی لی احکم*؛*الی-تبیان*)۔  

"میسینجرز" (*مرسالین*) کے دائرہ کار کی وضاحت میں ایک اہم موڑ پیدا ہوتا ہے۔ سنی مبصرین جیسے الراجی اس اصطلاح کو نبیوں تک محدود کرتے ہیں ، اور محمد کے پیغام کی حتمی بات پر زور دیتے ہیں (*مافاتیہ الغیب*)۔ اس کے برعکس ، شیعہ اسکالرز جیسے القومی اور تبتابائی نے اماموں کو شامل کرنے کے لئے اپنا اطلاق بڑھایا ، جسے وہ پیشن گوئی کی حکمت کے وارث سمجھتے ہیں (*طافسیر القمی*؛*المزان*)۔ یہ الہی رہنمائی کے تسلسل کے طور پر * امامہ * کے شیعہ مذہبی اصول کی عکاسی کرتا ہے ، جبکہ سنی کی توثیق محمد کے ساتھ وحی کی بندش کو ترجیح دیتی ہے۔  

یہ تشریحات مذہبی رواج کو متاثر کرتی ہیں: پیشن گوئی کی حتمی بات پر سنی پر زور دینے سے قرآن مجید اور سنت کی پابندی کو تقویت ملتی ہے جیسا کہ ساتھیوں کے ذریعہ منتقل کیا جاتا ہے ، جبکہ شیعہ کمیونٹیز روحانی اطاعت کے بارے میں ان کی تفہیم میں اماموں سے عقیدت کو مربوط کرتی ہیں۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ اختلافات حضرت کی موت کے بعد قیادت اور اتھارٹی کے بارے میں ابتدائی بحث و مباحثے سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں ، شیعہ ہرمینیٹکس اے ایچ ایل ال بیت کے تقدس کے عینک سے رہنمائی میں سمجھے جانے والے فرق کو دور کرنے کے لئے تیار ہوتے ہیں۔  

تاہم ، دونوں روایات الہی سچائی کو تسلیم کرنے کے لئے آیت کو اخلاقی لازمی قرار دینے میں متحد ہوجاتی ہیں۔ جیسا کہ تبتابائی نوٹ کرتا ہے ، تفتیش فرقہ وارانہ تقسیم سے آگے بڑھ جاتی ہے ، اور خدا کے منتخب کردہ رہنماؤں (*المزان*) کے ذریعہ راستبازی کا تعاقب کرنے کے لئے تمام مومنین کو اپنے فرض کی یاد دلاتی ہے۔ اس طرح کے اجتماعات اور تغیرات اسلام کی متحرک تشریحی روایت کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں ، جس کی جڑیں مذہبی تنوع کو ایڈجسٹ کرتے ہوئے وحی کے لئے مشترکہ عقیدت سے جڑی ہوئی ہیں۔

Both Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* and Tabrisi in *Majma al-Bayan* emphasize that this verse transcends mere historical inquiry into past communities’ responses to prophets; it encapsulates the universal principle of human responsibility toward God’s appointed guides in every era.

66.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qasas verse 66, Allah describes a profound state of confusion on the Day of Judgment: *"Fa’amiyat ‘alayhimul-anbā’u yawma’idhin fa-hum lā yatasā’alūn"*—a day when all means of understanding "the news" (al-anbā’) will be obscured, leaving people unable to seek clarity even from one another. This verse, revealed during the Meccan period, addresses the fate of those who rejected divine guidance, using imagery rooted in the Quranic theme of ultimate reckoning. The term *anbā’* refers to truths, messages, or critical information—here, the very knowledge people once dismissed or distorted in worldly life. The word *‘amiyat* (blinded or obscured) evokes spiritual blindness, a consequence of persistently ignoring truth.  

Shia tafsir, as explained by scholars like Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, emphasizes that this verse reflects the collapse of worldly systems of knowledge. On that Day, disbelievers will find their usual sources of information—tribal loyalties, material logic, or false leaders—useless. Their inability to *yatasā’alūn* (ask one another) signifies total isolation; no collaboration or excuses will remain. Historically, this resonated with early Muslims persecuted in Mecca, reminding them that oppressive structures would face divine reversal.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse underscores the urgency of grounding oneself in authentic guidance *now*. Just as the verse warns against relying on hollow sources of knowledge, Shia teachings urge adherence to the Quran and the Ahlul Bayt, who illuminate truth amidst confusion. Practically, this means prioritizing spiritual clarity over fleeting trends, seeking wisdom from reliable scholars, and fostering communities rooted in mutual support and truth-seeking. The inability to "ask" in the Hereafter reminds us to build meaningful connections today—to question, learn, and uphold justice collectively, ensuring our spiritual vision remains unclouded by worldly distractions.
66.layer2:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:66), Allah describes the state of disarray among disbelievers on the Day of Judgment, where divine truths become obscured to them, rendering them unable to seek clarity even from one another. Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, interpret this verse as a manifestation of the spiritual and intellectual confusion that engulfs those who rejected divine guidance in worldly life. 

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, explains that "the information" (*al-anba*') refers to the truths of faith, divine signs, and accountability that were once accessible through prophetic teachings but were ignored or denied. On the Day of Judgment, the veils of arrogance and heedlessness are lifted, yet the disbelievers’ inability to "ask one another" signifies their utter helplessness and the collapse of worldly systems of denial. This aligns with the Shia theological principle that divine justice necessitates clarity in accountability, yet those who persist in rejecting truth are deprived of the capacity to rectify their errors when the reality of the Hereafter is unveiled.

Tabatabai, in *Al-Mizan*, emphasizes the psychological and existential paralysis described in the verse. He notes that the Qur’an frequently links moral and intellectual blindness in this world to spiritual consequences in the next. The Shia tradition particularly underscores the role of the Imams as the "speaking Qur’an" and guides to these truths; their rejection thus leaves individuals directionless in both realms. The verse also resonates with the Shia understanding of *ghaybah* (occultation), where the obscured presence of the Imam tests humanity’s commitment to seeking truth despite ambiguity. 

Jurisprudentially, the verse reinforces the obligation to pursue knowledge (*talab al-ilm*) and adhere to divine stewardship (*wilayah*), as negligence in these duties leads to eternal bewilderment. The silence among the disbelievers reflects their internalized recognition of failure, a theme echoed in Shia narrations depicting the Day of Judgment as a moment when "every soul will be confronted with what it wrought" (Qur’an 14:22), devoid of excuses or communal solidarity.
66.layer3:
In Surah Al-Qasas 28:66, the Quran paints a haunting image of humanity’s disorientation on the Day of Judgment, where critical knowledge becomes inaccessible and dialogue breaks down. Contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasize that this verse warns against reliance on transient, ego-driven sources of truth—a theme amplified in today’s age of information overload and algorithmic echo chambers. In his *Tafsir Nemuneh*, he notes that the “unapparent information” here symbolizes the collapse of worldly systems of knowledge when confronted with divine reality, urging believers to anchor themselves in transcendent truths.

Modern thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this verse to today’s crisis of epistemological confusion, where misinformation and social media fragmentation leave societies polarized and spiritually adrift. The verse’s depiction of people being unable to “ask one another” resonates with the breakdown of meaningful dialogue in an era of performative debates and cancel culture. Neuroscientific studies on cognitive dissonance and confirmation bias further illuminate how humans instinctively avoid truths that challenge their identities—a dynamic the verse critiques on a cosmic scale.

Globally, this verse speaks to crises like climate denialism and geopolitical conflicts, where short-term interests obscure long-term truths. From an interfaith lens, parallels emerge in Buddhist teachings on “avidya” (ignorance) and Christian reflections on the Last Judgment, fostering a shared ethical imperative to prioritize collective truth-seeking over tribalistic divides. For Shia Muslims, this underscores the necessity of the Ahlul Bayt’s guidance—a timeless compass in navigating both spiritual and societal labyrinths. Ultimately, the verse calls for cultivating humility, critical consciousness, and reliance on divine wisdom amid modernity’s noise.
66.layer4:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:66), Allah describes a haunting state of confusion on the Day of Judgment when souls are severed from truth, unable to seek clarity or guidance from one another. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) unveil this verse as a profound warning about the spiritual blindness that arises from rejecting divine guidance (Wilayah) in earthly life. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) states, *"On that Day, tongues will stammer, hearts will tremble, and eyes will turn away—for they rejected the Light of Allah in their Imam."* This "Light" refers to the eternal guidance embodied in the Imamah, the spiritual authority of the 12 Imams, who are the living interpreters of the Quran and the sole means to avoid such bewilderment.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explains that *"the 'unapparent information' refers to the truths they ignored despite the clarity of the Imam’s call. Their hearts were veiled by worldly attachments, so they lose the capacity to discern truth in the Hereafter."* The verse thus underscores the inseparable link between recognizing the Ahlul Bayt’s wilayah in this life and attaining certainty in the next. Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) teaches that *"the soul’s clarity on Judgment Day is cultivated by daily remembrance of Allah through the Imams, for they are the Ark of Salvation in the storm of doubt."*

Practically, this verse urges believers to anchor their hearts to the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt through daily duas like Ziyarat Ashura, seeking their intercession (tawassul), and studying their sermons. The spiritual "vision" to navigate the horrors of the Hereafter is earned only by embracing the Imams as guides in worship, ethics, and love. As Imam Ali (peace be upon him) reminds us, *"Whoever lives in confusion in this world will die in confusion, and be resurrected in confusion."* Clarity in faith begins and ends with loyalty to the Ahlul Bayt.

66.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Qasas 28:66, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on the verse’s eschatological context, depicting the Day of Judgment as a moment of profound disorientation for disbelievers. Scholars across traditions, including Tabari (Sunni) and Tabatabai (Shia), agree that “the information will be unapparent” signifies the collapse of worldly means of communication and comprehension, leaving individuals isolated and unable to seek answers collectively. Ibn Kathir and Tabrisi both contextualize this within the Quran’s broader themes of divine accountability, emphasizing humanity’s helplessness before divine judgment.

A key divergence arises in theological implications. Sunni commentators like Qurtubi and Razi frame the verse as underscoring individual responsibility, interpreting the inability to “ask one another” as a consequence of rejecting prophetic guidance during worldly life. This aligns with Sunni emphasis on personal adherence to Quranic injunctions. Shia exegetes such as Qummi and Tusi, while affirming individual accountability, often link the verse to the necessity of divinely appointed guidance (Imamate). Al-Mizan posits that confusion stems from rejecting the Ahl al-Bayt’s role as interpreters of divine truth, suggesting that recognition of the Imams in this life averts spiritual blindness in the hereafter.

These differences reflect distinct theological frameworks: Sunni interpretations prioritize prophetic tradition (Sunnah) and communal consensus, while Shia readings integrate the Imams’ authority into Quranic hermeneutics. Historically, these divergences emerged from early debates over leadership and interpretive authority post-Prophet Muhammad, crystallizing in later exegetical traditions. Both perspectives reinforce the centrality of divine guidance but differ in its earthly manifestation—affecting Shia emphasis on allegiance to the Imams and Sunni focus on individual engagement with scripture. Such nuances remain scholarly rather than sectarian, rooted in complementary explorations of Quranic ontology.

66.layer2short: In Surah Al-Qasas (28:66), Allah describes the state of disarray among disbelievers on the Day of Judgment, where divine truths become obscured to them, rendering them unable to seek clarity even from one another. Classical Shia exegetes, drawing from the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, interpret this verse as a manifestation of the spiritual and intellectual confusion that engulfs those who rejected divine guidance in worldly life.
66.layer2short_urdu: سورہ القاساس (28:66) میں ، اللہ نے فیصلے کے دن کافروں کے درمیان بد نظمی کی حالت کو بیان کیا ہے ، جہاں خدائی سچائیاں ان کے لئے مبہم ہوجاتی ہیں ، اور انہیں ایک دوسرے سے بھی وضاحت نہیں ڈھونڈ سکتے ہیں۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ ، اہل بیت کی تعلیمات سے ملتے ہوئے ، اس آیت کو روحانی اور فکری الجھن کے مظہر کی ترجمانی کرتے ہیں جو دنیاوی زندگی میں خدائی رہنمائی کو مسترد کرنے والوں کو گھیرے میں لیتے ہیں۔

67.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:67), Allah outlines the path to eternal success through three transformative steps: repentance (*tawbah*), belief (*iman*), and righteous action (*amal salih*). The verse offers profound hope, promising that those who embody these qualities will join "the successful" (*al-mufliheen*)—a term referring not to worldly gain but to ultimate triumph in the hereafter. Shia scholars like Allamah Tabatabai in *Tafsir al-Mizan* emphasize that *tawbah* here signifies a sincere return to Allah, rooted in self-accountability and abandonment of past wrongs. *Iman* encompasses both intellectual conviction and heartfelt submission to divine truths, while *amal salih* involves aligning one’s deeds with Quranic ethics and the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt, who exemplify true righteousness.  

Historically, this Meccan verse reassured early Muslims facing persecution that material hardship wouldn’t define their fate—salvation lay in spiritual integrity. The phrase "*asā an yakūna min al-mufliheen*" (it is promised… he will be among the successful) carries gentle certainty, reflecting Allah’s boundless mercy for those who sincerely reform. Classical commentaries link this to the Prophet’s teachings that true success lies in purification of the soul and adherence to divine guidance through life’s trials.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse invites continuous self-renewal. *Tawbah* becomes a daily practice of seeking forgiveness and refining intentions. *Iman* challenges us to deepen our understanding of divine truths through Quranic study and the wisdom of the Ahlul Bayt. *Amal salih* calls for integrating faith into actions—prioritizing justice, kindness, and community welfare. In a world distracted by transient goals, this triad reminds us that lasting success is earned through spiritual discipline, unwavering trust in Allah’s plan, and conscious efforts to embody prophetic values in every choice.
67.layer2:
In his seminal *Al-Mizan*, Allamah Tabatabai elucidates that this verse encapsulates the tripartite path to divine success: repentance (*tawbah*), faith (*iman*), and righteous action (*amal salih*). Classical Shia exegesis, as reflected in Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, underscores that *tawbah* here transcends mere verbal remorse, demanding a transformative return to Allah through both inward contrition and outward reformation. Tabrisi notes that such repentance is intrinsically linked to divine grace (*lutf*), which enables the sinner to actualize spiritual renewal, a theme resonant with Shia theology’s emphasis on synergy between human agency and God’s enabling mercy.

The verse’s promise of success (*falāh*) is interpreted by Shia scholars as encompassing both temporal prosperity and eternal salvation, though the latter is paramount. Tabatabai observes that *falāh* in its ultimate sense denotes admission to the proximity of Allah, achievable only through adherence to the covenant of *wilayah* (divinely ordained guardianship). This aligns with the Shia doctrinal position that true *iman* necessitates affirmation of the Imamate, as articulated by Imam Jafar al-Sadiq in traditions stressing that faith devoid of allegiance to the Ahl al-Bayt remains incomplete.

Righteous action (*amal salih*), per Shia jurisprudence, is defined by conformity to the *sharia* as preserved and expounded through the teachings of the Imams. Classical commentators, including Al-Fayd al-Kashani, correlate such actions with the fulfillment of obligations (*wajibat*) and supererogatory acts (*nawafil*) framed within the ethos of love (*tawalli*) for the Ahl al-Bayt and dissociation (*tabarri*) from their oppressors. The verse thus integrates ethical, doctrinal, and jurisprudential dimensions, reflecting the Shia worldview wherein salvation is inseparable from the recognition of divine guidance manifested in the Imams. Success, as promised here, is thus contingent upon a holistic alignment of the soul, creed, and conduct with the luminous path of the Quran and the Prophetic Household.
67.layer3:
Contemporary Shia scholars, such as Ayatollah Naser Makarim Shirazi and Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari, interpret Surah Qasas 28:67 as a dynamic call to *transformative hope* rooted in action. They emphasize that “success” (*al-mufliheen*) here transcends mere spiritual salvation; it integrates ethical agency in a world grappling with existential crises. Shirazi notes in his *Tafsir Namuna* that repentance (*tawbah*) is not passive regret but a conscious recalibration of one’s relationship with societal structures—a theme resonant in modern discussions on social justice and systemic inequity. 

Neuroscientific insights into neuroplasticity, as explored by scholars like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali, align with this view: the verse’s triad of repentance, faith, and action reflects the brain’s capacity to rewire through sustained moral practice, fostering resilience against despair. Philosophically, thinkers such as Dr. Shomali link this “success” to existentialist notions of meaning-making in a secular age, where purpose is often fragmented by materialism or nihilism. 

Globally, the verse speaks to climate activism, economic reform, and mental health struggles. Engaging in “righteous deeds” today might involve advocating for environmental stewardship (echoing Imam Ali’s emphasis on caring for creation) or fostering interfaith solidarity amid rising polarization. The Ahlul Bayt’s teachings on social responsibility, as highlighted by contemporary Shia NGOs, reframe “success” as communal uplift—such as combating poverty or Islamophobia. 

Interfaith parallels emerge in Pope Francis’ *Laudato Si’*, which similarly ties spiritual renewal to ecological justice. In multicultural societies, this verse invites dialogue on shared ethical imperatives: success as collective flourishing, not individual gain. Modern challenges demand that faith communities embody this Quranic hope through actionable compassion, blending classical piety with 21st-century relevance.
67.layer4:
The verse's promise of *falah* (ultimate success) through tawbah (repentance), iman (faith), and righteous deeds is profoundly illuminated by the teachings of the Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them). Imam Ja'far al-Sadiq (as) taught that true *tawbah* is not merely regret for sins but "returning to Allah with the heart, tongue, and limbs," requiring both inner transformation and outward reform. The "success" here refers not to worldly gain but to salvation through spiritual alignment with Divine Will, attainable only through the guidance of those appointed by Allah – the Ahlul Bayt.

In *Tafsir al-Qummi*, Imam Muhammad al-Baqir (as) explains that true *iman* (faith) cannot exist without *wilayah* – loving allegiance to the purified Household of the Prophet (pbuh). A hadith in *Bihar al-Anwar* states: "Faith is built upon four pillars: trust in Allah, submission to His decree, contentment with His judgment, and entrusting affairs to Him – and these are perfected through our wilayah." Thus, the "righteous deeds" mentioned in the verse are only accepted when performed in recognition of the Imamah, as Lady Fatimah (as) declared in her Fadak sermon: "Deeds are validated through *ittiba'* (following) the Guides."

Practical guidance flows from Imam Ali's (as) counsel: "Let your repentance be the repentance of those approaching death – leaving sin without thought of return." Daily self-accounting (*muhasabah*), seeking forgiveness at dawn (as per Imam Sadiq's emphasis on *astaghfirullah* 70 times before sunrise), and aligning one's actions with the Imams' ethical teachings become the path to this Quranic *falah*. Success here is ultimately Divine mercy granted through the intercession of the Ahlul Bayt, who are the "Ark of Salvation" in the stormy seas of existence.
67.layer1_urdu:
سورہ القاساس (28:67) میں ، اللہ نے تین تغیراتی اقدامات کے ذریعے ابدی کامیابی کی راہ کا خاکہ پیش کیا: توبہ (*توبہ*) ، عقیدہ (*ایمان*) ، اور راستباز عمل (*امل سالہ*)۔ آیت کی گہری امید کی پیش کش کی گئی ہے ، اور یہ وعدہ کیا گیا ہے کہ جو لوگ ان خصوصیات کو مجسم بناتے ہیں وہ "دی کامیاب" (*المفلیہین*) میں شامل ہوں گے-ایک اصطلاح جس کا ذکر دنیاوی حصول کا نہیں بلکہ اس کے بعد حتمی فتح کا ہے۔ * طافسیر المزان * میں الامہ تبتابائی جیسے شیعہ اسکالرز اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ * توبہ * یہاں اللہ کی طرف سے مخلصانہ واپسی کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، جس کی جڑیں خود محاسبیت اور ماضی کی غلطیوں کو ترک کرنے میں مبتلا ہیں۔ * ایمان* الہی سچائیوں کے لئے دانشورانہ یقین اور دلی طور پر دونوں کو شامل کرتا ہے ، جبکہ* امل سالہ* میں قرآنی اخلاقیات اور اہل بیت کی تعلیمات کے ساتھ کسی کے اعمال کو سیدھ کرنا شامل ہے ، جو حقیقی راستبازی کی مثال دیتے ہیں۔  

تاریخی طور پر ، اس میکن آیت نے ابتدائی مسلمانوں کو ظلم و ستم کا سامنا کرنا پڑا کہ مادی مشکلات ان کی تقدیر کی وضاحت نہیں کریں گی۔ "*asā Yakūna min almuflihen*" کا جملہ (اس کا وعدہ کیا گیا ہے… وہ کامیاب افراد میں شامل ہوگا) نرمی کی یقین دہانی کراتا ہے ، جو ان لوگوں کے لئے اللہ کی حد سے زیادہ رحمت کی عکاسی کرتا ہے جو مخلصانہ اصلاحات کرتے ہیں۔ کلاسیکی تبصرے اس کو نبی of کی تعلیمات سے جوڑتے ہیں کہ حقیقی کامیابی روح کی تطہیر میں ہے اور زندگی کی آزمائشوں کے ذریعہ الہی رہنمائی پر عمل پیرا ہے۔  

ہم عصر مسلمانوں کے لئے ، یہ آیت مسلسل خود تجدید کی دعوت دیتی ہے۔ * توبہ* معافی مانگنے اور ارادوں کو بہتر بنانے کا روزمرہ کا عمل بن جاتا ہے۔ * ایمان* ہمیں چیلنج کرتا ہے کہ قرآنی مطالعے اور اہل بیت کی حکمت کے ذریعہ خدائی سچائیوں کے بارے میں اپنی تفہیم کو گہرا کریں۔ * امل صالح* عقیدے کو اعمال میں ضم کرنے کا مطالبہ کرتا ہے۔ عارضی اہداف سے مشغول دنیا میں ، یہ سہ رخی ہمیں یاد دلاتی ہے کہ دیرپا کامیابی روحانی نظم و ضبط ، اللہ کے منصوبے پر غیر متزلزل اعتماد ، اور ہر انتخاب میں پیشن گوئی کی اقدار کو مجسم بنانے کے لئے شعوری کوششوں کے ذریعے حاصل کی جاتی ہے۔
67.layer2_urdu:
اپنے سیمنل*المزان*میں ، الامہ تبتابائی نے یہ واضح کیا ہے کہ یہ آیت الہی کامیابی کے سہ فریقی راستے کو سمیٹتی ہے: توبہ (*توبہ*) ، ایمان (*ایمان*) ، اور راستباز عمل (*امل سالہ*)۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ ، جیسا کہ تبریسی کے *مجرو البیان *میں ظاہر ہوتا ہے ، اس بات کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے کہ *توبہ *یہاں محض زبانی پچھتاوا سے بالاتر ہے ، اور اندرونی تضاد اور ظاہری اصلاح دونوں کے ذریعہ اللہ کی تبدیلی کا مطالبہ کرتا ہے۔ تبریسی نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ اس طرح کی توبہ کو اندرونی طور پر الہی فضل (*لوٹف*) سے منسلک کیا گیا ہے ، جو گنہگار کو روحانی تجدید کو حقیقت میں لانے کے قابل بناتا ہے ، جو ایک تھیم انسانی ایجنسی اور خدا کی رحمت کے ساتھ ہم آہنگی پر زور دینے پر شیعہ الہیات کے زور پر ہے۔

آیت کی کامیابی کے وعدے (*فلاح*) کی ترجمانی شیعہ اسکالرز نے کی ہے جس میں دنیاوی خوشحالی اور ابدی نجات دونوں کو شامل کیا گیا ہے ، حالانکہ مؤخر الذکر اہم ہے۔ تبتابائی نے مشاہدہ کیا ہے کہ * فلاح * اپنے حتمی معنوں میں اللہ کی قربت میں داخلے کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے ، جو صرف * ولیہ * (خدائی طور پر مقرر کردہ سرپرستی) کے عہد کی پابندی کے ذریعہ قابل حصول ہے۔ یہ شیعہ نظریاتی حیثیت کے ساتھ صف بندی کرتا ہے کہ سچ * ایمان * امامیٹ کی تصدیق کی ضرورت ہے ، جیسا کہ امام جعفر السادق نے روایات میں بیان کیا ہے کہ اس بات پر زور دیا گیا ہے کہ اہل البائٹ سے عقیدت سے عاری عقیدہ نامکمل ہے۔

نیک عمل (*امل سالہ*) ، فی شیعہ فقہ ،*شریعت*کے مطابق ہونے کے ذریعہ اس کی تعریف کی گئی ہے جیسا کہ اماموں کی تعلیمات کے ذریعہ محفوظ اور بیان کیا گیا ہے۔ کلاسیکی مبصرین ، بشمول الفید الکاشانی ، اس طرح کے اقدامات کو ذمہ داریوں کی تکمیل (*Wajibat*) اور سپرریجیٹری اعمال (*نوافیل*) سے محبت کے اخلاق (*طوالی*) کے اندر اپنے مخالفوں سے اخلاقیات (*طوالی*) کے ساتھ تیار کیے گئے ہیں۔ اس طرح آیت اخلاقی ، نظریاتی اور فقہ کے طول و عرض کو مربوط کرتی ہے ، جو شیعہ کے عالمی نظریہ کی عکاسی کرتی ہے جس میں نجات کو اماموں میں ظاہر ہونے والے الہی رہنمائی کی پہچان سے الگ نہیں کیا جاسکتا ہے۔ کامیابی ، جیسا کہ یہاں وعدہ کیا گیا ہے ، اس طرح قرآن اور پیشن گوئی کے گھر والے کے برائٹ راہ کے ساتھ روح ، مسلک اور طرز عمل کی ایک جامع صف بندی کا مقابلہ ہے۔

*طافسیر القومی *میں ، امام محمد البقیر (ع) نے وضاحت کی ہے کہ سچ *ایمان *(ایمان) *ولیہ *کے بغیر موجود نہیں ہوسکتا ہے-نبی صلی اللہ علیہ وسلم کے صاف گھر سے محبت کرنے والی بیعت (ص)۔ * بہار الانور * میں ایک حدیث میں کہا گیا ہے کہ: "عقیدہ چار ستونوں پر بنایا گیا ہے: اللہ پر اعتماد ، اس کے فرمان کے تابع ہونا ، اس کے فیصلے پر راضی ہونا ، اور اس کے سپرد کرنے کے معاملات-اور یہ ہمارے ولیہ کے ذریعے مکمل ہیں۔" اس طرح ، آیت میں مذکور "نیک اعمال" کو صرف اس وقت قبول کیا جاتا ہے جب امامہ کے اعتراف میں انجام دیا جاتا ہے ، جیسا کہ لیڈی فاطمہ (ع) نے اپنے فڈک خطبے میں اعلان کیا تھا: "اعمال کو * اتٹیبا ' * (مندرجہ ذیل رہنماؤں کے ذریعے توثیق کیا جاتا ہے۔"

67.layer5:
In interpreting Surah Al-Qasas 28:67, both Shia and Sunni exegetes converge on core principles: sincere repentance (tawbah), authentic faith (iman), and righteous action (amal salih) as prerequisites for divine success (fulah). Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tabrisi (Shia) emphasize that these conditions are inseparable, with Al-Tabari framing success as eternal salvation contingent upon divine mercy, while Al-Tabrisi notes Allah’s promise here reflects His unwavering commitment to reward spiritual transformation. Ibn Kathir (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) both contextualize the verse within the Quranic narratives of Pharaoh’s rejection versus Moses’ steadfastness, underscoring human accountability amid divine guidance.  

Divergences emerge in theological nuances. Al-Razi (Sunni) highlights God’s absolute will in granting success, aligning with Sunni emphasis on divine predestination (qadar), whereas Al-Tabatabai (Shia) stresses the inherent causality between moral reform and salvation, reflecting the Shia principle of divine justice (adl) requiring equitable recompense. Al-Qummi (Shia) and Al-Qurtubi (Sunni) differ subtly on repentance’s scope: Al-Qurtubi prioritizes individual adherence to the Prophet’s Sunnah, while Al-Qummi’s narration via Imam al-Baqir links true tawbah to adherence to the Ahl al-Bayt’s guidance, a distinctive Shia theological tenet.  

Practically, Sunni interpretations often reinforce communal orthodoxy and ritual observance as markers of righteousness, whereas Shia exegesis intertwines ethical action with loyalty to the Imams. These differences stem from historical developments in authority structures post-Prophet Muhammad, with Sunni thought crystallizing around caliphal legitimacy and scholarly consensus (ijma), while Shia hermeneutics centered on Imamah as an extension of prophetic wisdom. Both traditions, however, unite in viewing this verse as an exhortation toward spiritual renewal and ethical rigor.

سورہ القاساس 28:67 کی ترجمانی کرتے ہوئے ، شیعہ اور سنی دونوں بنیادی اصولوں پر تبادلہ خیال کرتے ہیں: مخلص توبہ (توبہ) ، مستند عقیدے (ایمان) ، اور نیک عمل (امل سالہ) الہی کامیابی (فولہ) کی شرائط کے طور پر۔ التباری (سنی) اور الاتبریسی (شیعہ) اس بات پر زور دیتے ہیں کہ یہ حالات لازم و ملزوم ہیں ، العباری کامیابی کے ساتھ الہی رحمت پر ابدی نجات کا دستہ بناتے ہیں ، جبکہ العبیریسی نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ اللہ کا وعدہ یہاں روحانی تبدیلی کے بدلہ دینے کے ان کی غیر متزلزل وابستگی کی عکاسی کرتا ہے۔ ابن کتھیر (سنی) اور التوسی (شیعہ) دونوں موسیٰ کی ثابت قدمی کے مقابلے میں فرعون کے مسترد ہونے کے قرآنی بیانیہ کے اندر آیت کو سیاق و سباق دیتے ہیں ، اور الہی رہنمائی کے درمیان انسانی احتساب کی نشاندہی کرتے ہیں۔  

مذہبی باریکیوں میں تغیرات ابھرتے ہیں۔ الراجی (سنی) خدا کی مطلق وصیت پر روشنی ڈالتی ہے ، کامیابی کی فراہمی میں ، الہی پیشن گوئی (قادر) پر سنی زور کے ساتھ صف بندی کرتے ہوئے ، جبکہ التباطابائی (شیعہ) اخلاقی اصلاحات اور نجات کے مابین موروثی وجہ پر زور دیتے ہیں ، جس سے الہامی انصاف (ADL) کے شیعہ اصول کی عکاسی ہوتی ہے جس میں مساوی بازیافت کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے۔ القومی (شیعہ) اور القوروبی (سنی) توبہ کے دائرہ کار پر بالکل مختلف ہیں: القوروبی نے نبی of کی سنت کی انفرادی حیثیت کو ترجیح دی ہے ، جبکہ الکوومی کا بیان امام البقیر کے ذریعہ الی بائٹ کے تقویت کے مطابق ، ایک البقیر کے تقویت کے مطابق ، ایک البقیر کے تقویت کے مطابق۔  

عملی طور پر ، سنی کی تشریحات اکثر فرقہ وارانہ آرتھوڈوکس اور رسمی طور پر رطوبت کے مارکر کے طور پر تقویت دیتے ہیں ، جبکہ شیعہ نے اخلاقی عمل کو اماموں کے ساتھ وفاداری کے ساتھ جوڑ دیا ہے۔ یہ اختلافات اتھارٹی کے ڈھانچے میں تاریخی پیشرفتوں سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں ، جس کے بعد پیش گوئی کے بعد محمد ، سنی کے خیال میں خلافت کے قانونی حیثیت اور علمی اتفاق رائے (آئی جے ایم اے) کے ارد گرد کرسٹللائزنگ ہوتی ہے ، جبکہ شیعہ ہرمینیٹکس امامہ پر پیشن گوئی کی حکمت کی توسیع کے طور پر مرکوز تھے۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات اس آیت کو روحانی تجدید اور اخلاقی سختی کی طرف نصیحت کے طور پر دیکھنے میں متحد ہوجاتی ہیں۔

Classical Shia exegesis, as reflected in Tabrisi’s *Majma al-Bayan*, underscores that *tawbah* here transcends mere verbal remorse, demanding a transformative return to Allah through both inward contrition and outward reformation. Tabrisi notes that such repentance is intrinsically linked to divine grace (*lutf*), which enables the sinner to actualize spiritual renewal, a theme resonant with Shia theology’s emphasis on synergy between human agency and God’s enabling mercy.
67.layer2short_urdu: اپنے سیمنل*المزان*میں ، الامہ تبتابائی نے یہ واضح کیا ہے کہ یہ آیت الہی کامیابی کے سہ فریقی راستے کو سمیٹتی ہے: توبہ (*توبہ*) ، ایمان (*ایمان*) ، اور راستباز عمل (*امل سالہ*)۔ کلاسیکی شیعہ استثنیٰ ، جیسا کہ تبریسی کے *مجرو البیان *میں ظاہر ہوتا ہے ، اس بات کی نشاندہی کرتا ہے کہ *توبہ *یہاں محض زبانی پچھتاوا سے بالاتر ہے ، اور اندرونی تضاد اور ظاہری اصلاح دونوں کے ذریعہ اللہ کی تبدیلی کا مطالبہ کرتا ہے۔ تبریسی نے نوٹ کیا ہے کہ اس طرح کی توبہ کو اندرونی طور پر الہی فضل (*لوٹف*) سے منسلک کیا گیا ہے ، جو گنہگار کو روحانی تجدید کو حقیقت میں لانے کے قابل بناتا ہے ، جو ایک تھیم انسانی ایجنسی اور خدا کی رحمت کے ساتھ ہم آہنگی پر زور دینے پر شیعہ الہیات کے زور پر ہے۔

68.layer1:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:68), Allah affirms His absolute authority over creation and selection, declaring: *"Your Lord creates what He wills and chooses; they have no power to choose. Glory be to Allah! He is exalted above what they associate with Him."* This verse addresses the core Islamic principle of *tawhid* (oneness of God), emphasizing that Allah alone holds the exclusive right to determine realities beyond human control, such as prophethood, natural laws, or the divine criteria for righteousness. The phrase *"yakhluq"* (He creates) and *"yakhtar"* (He chooses) highlight Allah’s sovereignty, while *"ma kana lahum al-khiyarah"* (they have no power to choose) negates any human claim to override divine will in matters inherently tied to Allah’s wisdom.  

Historical reports suggest this verse responded to pagan objections to Prophet Muhammad’s (PBUH) mission, as they questioned why Allah would choose a prophet from outside their tribal elite. It also countered their practice of arbitrarily worshipping idols or attributing divine powers to created beings. The closing declaration *"Subhan Allah wa ta’ala ‘amma yushrikun"* (Glory be to Allah, exalted above what they associate) rejects all forms of shirk, whether through literal idolatry or modern ideologies that prioritize human desires over divine guidance.  

Today, this verse reminds believers to trust Allah’s wisdom in life’s trials and societal challenges, resisting the urge to "choose" self-serving interpretations of faith or resent divine decrees. For Shia Muslims, it reinforces the belief in divinely appointed leadership (Imamah), as the Ahlul Bayt were chosen by Allah, not human consensus. By internalizing this verse, Muslims cultivate humility, avoid arrogance in spiritual matters, and recognize that true success lies in aligning their limited choices with Allah’s eternal will.
68.layer2:
In Surah al-Qasas 28:68, the verse underscores Allah’s absolute sovereignty in creation and selection, rejecting any human claim to autonomy in divine matters. Classical Shia exegetes emphasize this as a cornerstone of *tawhid* (divine unity), affirming that Allah’s will transcends human limitations and preferences. Al-Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, interprets the phrase *"your Lord creates what He wills and chooses"* as a direct refutation of polytheistic beliefs, noting that human beings lack the authority to dictate or question divine choices, whether in matters of prophethood, imamate, or cosmic order. This aligns with the Shia theological principle of *al-mashee’ah al-ilahiyyah* (divine volition), which posits that Allah’s choices arise from His infinite wisdom (*hikmah*) and justice (*‘adl*), not arbitrary will.

Al-Tabrisi further explains that the verse’s second clause—*"not for them was the choice"*—rejects the pre-Islamic Arab practice of arbitrarily assigning divine status to idols, while also implicitly critiquing historical deviations in leadership succession. Here, Shia scholars like Al-Tabtabai in *Al-Mizan* draw a doctrinal link to the *imamah*, asserting that just as prophets are divinely appointed, so too are the Imams from the Ahl al-Bayt, whose authority stems solely from Allah’s decree, not human election. This ties into the Shia rejection of the Saqifah event and the concept of *shura* (consultation) as a basis for leadership, framing it as a usurpation of divine prerogative.

The closing declaration, *"Exalted is Allah... above what they associate,"* reinforces *tanzih* (Allah’s transcendence), negating any anthropocentric projections onto the divine. Al-Tabtabai highlights how this verse integrates theology with jurisprudence: by affirming Allah’s exclusive right to legislate and appoint guides, it establishes the ontological foundation for Shia adherence to divinely ordained teachings. Thus, the verse encapsulates the Shia worldview, where divine authority—manifest in the Prophet and Imams—remains inseparable from Allah’s unassailable will.
68.layer3:
In Surah Al-Qasas 28:68, contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarem Shirazi emphasize the interplay between divine sovereignty and human agency. The verse underscores Allah’s absolute authority in creation and selection, while modern thinkers like Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali connect this to existential humility—a counterbalance to humanity’s often unchecked arrogance in the Anthropocene era. Here, the Quranic rejection of *shirk* extends beyond idolatry to critique modern materialism, techno-utopianism, and the illusion of human control over ecosystems or destiny.  

Scientifically, the verse resonates with quantum indeterminacy and cosmic fine-tuning, where randomness in subatomic particles coexists with precise universal constants. Physicists like Stephen Hawking acknowledged the “fine-tuned universe” concept, which Shia scholars such as Sayyid Rizwan Arastu frame as evidence of divine *ikhtiyar* (choosing), harmonizing faith with empirical inquiry. Socially, the verse challenges systemic inequalities and climate injustice, urging societies to recognize their limitations amid global crises.  

Interfaith dialogues, particularly with Christian and Jewish theologians, highlight shared themes of divine providence. Jesuit priest Fr. David Bentley Hart’s work on cosmic purpose aligns with this Quranic vision, fostering multicultural solidarity against nihilism. The verse’s call to transcend “what they associate” speaks to today’s identity politics and ideological tribalism, advocating unity through submission to a higher wisdom.  

Ultimately, this verse invites a reorientation: embracing uncertainty with faith, pursuing justice without hubris, and seeking harmony with creation—a timeless message made urgent by 21st-century challenges. As Ayatollah Khamenei notes in *Islamic Teachings in Brief*, recognizing divine authority isn’t passive fatalism but a catalyst for ethical action grounded in humility.
68.layer4:
In Surah Al-Qasas (28:68), Allah affirms His absolute sovereignty in creation and divine selection, emphasizing that true authority to "choose" lies solely with Him. The Ahlul Bayt (ع) illuminated this verse as a profound declaration of *tawhid* in leadership (*imamah*) and servitude. Imam Ali (ع) states in Nahj al-Balagha: *"Allah selects for His authority whom He wills... not to elevate their stature, but to purify hearts through their guidance."* This underscores that Allah’s choice of Prophets and Imams transcends human merit or desire; it is a mercy to creation, not a privilege for the chosen.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (ع) explains this verse in *Al-Kafi*: *"The ‘choice’ denied to people refers to leadership (wilayah) — it is Allah’s right alone to appoint His guides, for hearts are tested through loyalty to them."* The verse thus refutes those who ascribe partners to Allah by rejecting divinely appointed guardians (the Imams) or seeking alternate paths to truth. Lady Fatimah (ع) encapsulated this in her sermon: *"Allah made obedience to us the structure of His unity and our love the safeguard against division."* 

Practically, this verse calls believers to submit to Allah’s wisdom in all matters, particularly by embracing the *wilayah* of the Ahlul Bayt (ع) as an extension of His will. Spiritually, it teaches humility: just as we cannot dictate divine decree, we must surrender our ego’s "choices" to the Imam’s guidance. By aligning our desires with the purified Imams (ع) — the manifest signs of Allah’s will — we transcend limited perception and embody the verse’s call to *"exalt Allah above what they associate."* True freedom lies not in arbitrary choice, but in attuning one’s heart to the Chosen Ones (ع) through whom Allah’s light emerges.

تاریخی رپورٹس سے پتہ چلتا ہے کہ اس آیت نے نبی اکرم (صلی اللہ علیہ وآلہ وسلم) مشن پر کافر اعتراضات کا جواب دیا ، کیونکہ انہوں نے سوال کیا کہ اللہ ان کے قبائلی طبقے کے باہر سے کسی نبی کا انتخاب کیوں کرے گا۔ اس نے من مانی طور پر بتوں کی پوجا کرنے یا تخلیق شدہ مخلوقات سے الہی طاقتوں کو منسوب کرنے کے ان کے طرز عمل کا بھی مقابلہ کیا۔ اختتامی اعلامیہ * "سبھن اللہ تعالٰی‘ امما یوشرکون " * (اللہ کی شان ، جس سے وہ اس سے وابستہ ہیں) شرک کی تمام شکلوں کو مسترد کرتے ہیں ، چاہے وہ لفظی بت پرستی یا جدید نظریات کے ذریعہ جو الہی رہنمائی سے زیادہ انسانی خواہشات کو ترجیح دیتے ہیں۔

68.layer5:
In interpreting Surah al-Qasas 28:68, Shia and Sunni scholars converge on core theological principles while offering distinct emphases reflective of their interpretive traditions. Both traditions unanimously affirm Allah’s absolute sovereignty (rububiyya) in creation and divine choice, rejecting any notion of human authority over divine will. Al-Tabari (Sunni) and al-Tabrisi (Shia) both emphasize that the verse negates human “choice” in determining Allah’s decrees, particularly regarding prophethood and cosmic order, as noted in *Jami al-Bayan* and *Majma al-Bayan*. Ibn Kathir and al-Tusi similarly stress Allah’s transcendence above associational claims (shirk), aligning with the verse’s explicit rejection of polytheism.  

A key divergence arises in contextualizing “choice” (ikhtiyar). Sunni exegetes like al-Qurtubi and al-Razi frame this within debates on predestination (qadar), interpreting “not for them was the choice” as a rejection of the Mu’tazilite emphasis on human autonomous will. In contrast, Shia commentators such as al-Tabatabai (*Al-Mizan*) and al-Qummi link the verse to the divine appointment (nass) of leadership, arguing that just as prophets are chosen by Allah alone, so too are the Imams—a theological extension rooted in the Shia doctrine of Imamah. This reflects differing conceptions of authority post-Prophethood, with Sunni scholars generally limiting the verse’s scope to prophethood and cosmic creation.  

Historically, these interpretations emerged from distinct theological priorities: Sunni exegesis engaged with early debates on free will and divine justice, while Shia tafsir developed within frameworks emphasizing divinely guided leadership. Both traditions, however, uphold the verse’s central message of Allah’s transcendence, with practical implications for affirming tawhid in worship and rejecting human imposition on divine wisdom. The differences illustrate how shared Quranic principles are contextualized within each school’s theological paradigm, without contradicting the verse’s unambiguous rejection of shirk.

68.layer2short: In Surah al-Qasas 28:68, the verse underscores Allah’s absolute sovereignty in creation and selection, rejecting any human claim to autonomy in divine matters. Classical Shia exegetes emphasize this as a cornerstone of *tawhid* (divine unity), affirming that Allah’s will transcends human limitations and preferences. Al-Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, interprets the phrase *"your Lord creates what He wills and chooses"* as a direct refutation of polytheistic beliefs, noting that human beings lack the authority to dictate or question divine choices, whether in matters of prophethood, imamate, or cosmic order. This aligns with the Shia theological principle of *al-mashee’ah al-ilahiyyah* (divine volition), which posits that Allah’s choices arise from His infinite wisdom (*hikmah*) and justice (*‘adl*), not arbitrary will.

In Surah Al-Qasas, verse 69, Allah declares, *“Wa Rabbuka ya‘lamu ma tukinnu sudooruhum wa ma yu‘linoon”* (And your Lord knows what their breasts conceal and what they declare). This verse emphasizes Allah’s all-encompassing knowledge of human intentions, secrets, and outward actions. The term *tukinnu* derives from *kanna*, meaning “to conceal,” while *sudoor* (chests) symbolise the inner self—the realm of thoughts, beliefs, and hidden motives. *Yu‘linoon*, meaning “they declare,” contrasts with *tukinnu*, highlighting the duality of human conduct: the visible and the concealed.  

Revealed in Mecca during a period of intense persecution, this verse reassured the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) and early Muslims that Allah knew the hypocrisy of those who opposed Islam privately while feigning ignorance publicly. It also comforted believers whose faith was internalised but not yet openly expressed due to fear. The verse reinforced the principle that accountability before Allah transcends superficial appearances, focusing instead on the sincerity of the heart—a theme central to Quranic teachings.  

For contemporary Muslims, this verse serves as a timeless reminder to cultivate *ikhlas* (sincerity) in worship and conduct. In an age where social media often prioritises image over authenticity, the call to align inner intentions with outward actions is vital. It encourages self-reflection: Are our prayers, charity, or good deeds performed for Allah’s pleasure or human validation? The verse also offers solace, affirming that Allah’s justice accounts for hidden struggles and unspoken pains, urging trust in His wisdom during trials. By internalising this truth, Muslims can strive for integrity, knowing that true success lies in purifying the heart—a teaching echoed by the Ahlul Bayt, who emphasised that “actions are but by intentions” (Imam Ali). Ultimately, this verse invites believers to live with God-consciousness, bridging the gap between the seen and unseen in their spiritual journey.
69.layer2:
In Surah al-Qasas (28:69), Allah declares, *“And your Lord knows what their breasts conceal and what they declare.”* Classical Shia exegetes emphasize this verse’s theological and ethical dimensions, anchoring their interpretations in the principles of divine omniscience, human accountability, and the interconnectedness of inward and outward states. As articulated by Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan*, this verse underscores Allah’s absolute knowledge (*‘ilm al-ghayb*), which transcends temporal and spatial limitations. Tabatabai notes that divine awareness encompasses both the *sirr* (hidden realities of the heart) and the *‘alaniyyah* (manifest actions), rendering human pretense or hypocrisy futile. This aligns with the Shia theological doctrine of divine justice (*‘adl*), whereby Allah’s judgment accounts for the totality of human intention and action, a principle integral to eschatological reckoning.

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, contextualizes this verse within the broader Meccan discourse on the Prophet’s mission, observing that it serves as both a warning to those who conceal disbelief (*kufr*) under the guise of compliance and a reassurance to believers whose sincere faith may remain hidden from hostile observers. The verse thus reinforces the Shia ethical framework, which prioritizes *ikhlas* (sincerity) in worship and moral conduct. Classical commentators, including Shaykh al-Tusi, link this principle to the necessity of *niyyah* (intention) in Islamic jurisprudence, as actions derive validity from their underlying spiritual orientation.

A distinct Shia theological emphasis emerges in connecting divine knowledge to the spiritual authority of the Ahl al-Bayt. As narrated in traditions from Imam Jafar al-Sadiq, the Imams’ inherited knowledge (*‘ilm al-wasiyyah*) grants them insight into the inner states of believers, though subordinate to Allah’s absolute awareness. This interplay between divine omniscience and the Imams’ guidance underscores the Shia belief in the necessity of divinely appointed leadership to nurture both outward adherence and inward purity. The verse thus resonates with the Shia existential posture of living between divine scrutiny and the aspirational pursuit of *wilayah* (devotion to Allah through the Ahl al-Bayt), a dynamic that informs both creed and practice.
69.layer3:
In contemporary Shia scholarship, Surah Al-Qasas 69 is often interpreted as a profound reminder of divine omniscience intersecting with modern questions of privacy, authenticity, and moral accountability. Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi, in his exegesis *Al-Amthal*, highlights how this verse dismantles the illusion of secrecy in human actions, urging believers to align their inner states with outward conduct—a principle echoed in Imam Ali’s teachings on *ikhlas* (sincerity). Modern scholars like Sayyid Kamal al-Haydari extend this to critique societal hypocrisy, where individuals or institutions perform virtue publicly while concealing unethical agendas—a phenomenon amplified by social media’s curated personas and political doublespeak.

Scientifically, advancements in neuroimaging and behavioral analytics reveal how subconscious biases and hidden intentions shape decisions, mirroring the Quranic assertion that “what their breasts conceal” impacts reality. Psychologists like Dr. G. Hussein Rassool note parallels between this verse and modern mental health frameworks, where suppressing true emotions (taqiyyah of the self) exacerbates anxiety, urging alignment between inner truth and expression. Ethicists also link this to corporate or governmental secrecy in crises like climate denial or data exploitation, where hidden motives harm collective well-being.

Interfaith dialogues, such as those led by the Al-Mahdi Institute, connect this verse to shared Abrahamic values—like Psalm 139’s “Lord, You know my inmost being”—emphasizing divine accountability as a universal check against oppression. In multicultural societies, it challenges individuals to transcend performative allyship and cultivate integrity amid rising polarization. Ultimately, this verse bridges timeless spirituality with modern existential struggles, affirming that divine awareness transcends human surveillance—offering both solace and a call to radical honesty in an age of masks.
69.layer4:
In the luminous verse of Surah Al-Qasas (28:69), Allah unveils His all-encompassing knowledge of both the hidden secrets of hearts and the outward actions of creation. The Ahlul Bayt (peace be upon them) taught that this verse is a profound call to purify one’s inner state, for true faith resides not in mere appearances but in the sincerity of the heart. Imam Ali (peace be upon him) declared, *“The most exalted worship is sincerity,”* emphasizing that Allah’s knowledge of our innermost realities demands that we align our hidden intentions with our outward worship.

Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) explained that this verse reveals the necessity of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship) as the foundation of faith. He taught: *“Allah weighs the intention behind deeds as He weighs the deeds themselves. He who claims to love us [the Ahlul Bayt] while his heart hides enmity is a liar before the Knower of Secrets.”* Here, the Imam connects the recognition of Allah’s omniscience to the necessity of wholehearted allegiance to the Imams, whose spiritual station allows them to perceive the truths within souls, as affirmed in Shia theology.

Lady Fatimah (peace be upon her) illuminated this truth in her sermon: *“Allah made faith your purification from polytheism, prayer your guard from arrogance, and sincerity the lifeblood of your deeds.”* This wisdom teaches that acknowledging Allah’s awareness of our hidden states compels believers to cultivate *ikhlas* (sincerity) through constant self-reflection, seeking the Imam’s guidance to cleanse the heart’s diseases.

Practically, this verse invites daily *muhasabah* (self-accounting). Imam Muhammad al-Baqir (peace be upon him) advised: *“Question your soul before you are questioned [by Allah].”* By aligning our inner convictions with the divine standards upheld by the Ahlul Bayt, we transform ritual into reality, ensuring our outward submission mirrors the heart’s secret yearning for the Truth.
